figure.head: THE Academy of Eloquence By Tho: Blount Gent:

div.p: THE ACADEMIE OF ELOQUENCE. Containing a Compleat ENGLISH RHETORIQUE, Exemplified, With Common-Places, and Formes, digeted into an eaie and Methodical way to peak and write, fluently, according to the mode of the preent times, Together with LETTERS both AMOROS and MORAL, Upon emergent occaions.
By THO. BLOUNT Gent'
LONDON, Printed by T. N. for Humphrey Moeley, at the Princes-Arm's in S. Paul's Church yard. 1654.

div.head: TO ALL NOBLE GENTLEMEN AND LADIES OF ENGLAND.
div.p: WEre it abolutely neceary for him that hould write of Eloquence to be perfectly Eloquent, I would eaily confes my elf too rah in this enterprie: But having een often thoe treat knowingly of Painting, that never held Pencill; and Cicero remarking that Aratus, by the comon conent of learned men, wrote excellently of the Heavens & Stars, though he was no celebrated Atronomer; I'm encourag'd to ay, Why then may not I too dicoure of Eloquence, without being a Orator?

Galen that great Mater of Phyick, who wrote o learnedly of every part of that Science, was little een in the Practick; Nor
are thoe, that dicoure bet of the embattailing Armys, and differencing military functions, alwaies the bet Warriers, or the mot daring. The like may happen in this ubject, that he, who is able to et down the Rules and Laws which ought to be oberv'd in Speech or tile, may notwithtanding find himelf defective in the application, and o may be aid to give that to others, which he has not himelf.

The conceits of the mind are Pictures, whoe Interpreter is the tongue, and the order of Gods Creatures in themelves, is not only admirable and glorious, but Eloquent; he then, that could apprehend the conequence of things in their truths, and deliver his apprehenions as truely, were a perfect Orator; Thus Cicero; Dicere recte nemo potet nii qui prudenter intelligit.

Eloquence is equally fortunate in taming Paions and in charming enes: he imitates Muick, and makes ue of the voice of Orators to enchant the Eares, with the cadence of Periods, and the harmony of Accents; whilt the getures, apt motions, Natural Aire, and all thoe graces, which accompany exact Recitation, teal away the Heart by the eyes, and work wonders upon the will. But Eloquence is chiefly grounded upon Widom, & Widom aries principally from a due pre-conideration of all our
actions; Hence that excellent aying of a modern French Author, Il et imposible de bien dire, ans avoir bien pené, 'tis impoible to peak well, without having firt well conidered what to peak. And Plotinus ays, 'tis widom to think upon any thing, before we execute it.

Now, as 'tis certain, that No harmony, can appear in his thoughts, nor oundnes in his reaon, whoe peech is faltering and prepoterous: So likewie no clearnes nor perfection in that Fancy, which delivers it elf by a confus'd abortion. Great is the diparagment which flows from the defailance of the Tongue: it not only dihonours the peron of the Speaker, but even ullys the opinion of his reaon and judgement with a direpute, and oft-times renders the very truth upected.

If then it o befall our verball expreions, which are tranient and les lyable to cenure, and where one hanome expreion may excue a number of olaecimes; how hall that peron be eteem'd prudent, whoe pen layes him wide open in a fungous and ordid tile; how hall we expect ingenuity from him, whoe leiure and Genius, asited with the examen of his eyes, yeild us no pirit in his writing? He that has worth in him and cannot expres it, is a Cabinet keeping a rich Jewell and the key lot, ayes a modern. Author; whereas a good tile,
with choie matter and embroidery of well choen words, is like a beautifull Woman with a virtuous Soul, who attracts the eyes and charmes the hearts of all beholders.

This excellent faculty of peech ha's bin in high eteem even from the very infancy, & will be to the end of the World; For in acred Story we read,Prov. 16.21, 24. the wie in Heart hall be called prudent and the weetnes of the lips increaeth undertanding: Pleaant words are as an honycomb; weet to the oul and health to the bones. Hence 'twas, an ancient Author maintained, that Pericles (the Orator) was no les Tyrant in Athens then Pyitratus; without acknowledging other difference, then that this exercis'd his Empire armed, the other without armes, by the ole terror of his peech, which Aritophanes compar'd to a thunder bolt, as Homer did that of Vlises to a Torrent, that beares down all with its violence. And 'twas aid of old, that the tongue of Cyneas (the fam'd Scholler of Demothenes) conquer'd more Citties, then the word of Pyrrhus, the valiant King of Epire.

To have aid thus much, of the much more might be added in behalf of this charming Faculty, and of the diadvantage commonly attending thoe who are unskill'd in it, may erve as an inducement to the youth of both
Sexes (for whoe benefit this little Work is chiefly intended, and to their acceptance conecrated) to make the peruall of it their ubervient Recreation for vacant houres, this wth little tudy, will not only facilitate your dicoure into the moding language of thee times, but adapt your pens too with a quaint & fluent tile, then which no qualities (with confidence I peak it) can render you more accomplih'd.
Here hall you be furniht with all neceary materialls and helps in order to the acquiring o great a treaure; uch helps as have bin advied and often wiht for, but never before publihed.
I. The firt part containes a more exact Englih Rhetorique, then has been hitherto extant, comprehending all the mot uefull Figures, exemplifi'd out of the Arcadia and other our choiet Authors.

II. In the econd part, you have formulae majores or Common-places, upon the mot uual ubjects for tile and peech; The ue and advantage whereof is aerted by my Lord Bacon, who (in his Advancement of learning) ayes thus; I hold the diligence and pain in collecting Common-places to be of great ue and certainty in tudying; as, that which aids the memory ubminiters copy to invention, and contracts the ight of judgement to a trength.

III. In the third place you hall find Formulae minores (as my Lord calls them) leer formes, which he then reckon'd among the defects in our Language, and sayes, they are as it were, the Portals and potern dores of tile and peech, and of no mal ue.

IV. Latly, you have a Collection of Letters and addrees written to, for, and by everall perons, upon emergent occaions; with ome particular Intructions and Rules premied, for the better attaining to a Pen-perfection.

The Formula's are but Analects, which like the Humble-bec I gather'd in Spring time out of the choiet Flowers of our Englih Garden; nor have I in the Rhetorick or Letters tranplanted much from my own barren Seminary; I may ay to ome noble Correpondents, what the Poet did of old in a like Cae, ic vos non vobis — But, you will eaily ditinguih Tinill from better mettal: what is mine will appear to be o, by the Bluntimes that frequently occur, the ret are of better allay; So that, if the defects of my own Eayes be but pardoned, the ret I am confident will abide the touch, and pas for Sterling.

div.head: AN Englih Rhetorique exemplified.
div.p:
FIgures and Tropes (ayes Alexander the Sophiter) are the vertues of Speech and Stile, as Barbarimes and Solecimes are the vices; we hall then begin with A METAPHOR or Tranlation is the friendly and neighbourly borrowing of a word, to expres a thing with more light and better note, though not o directly and properly as the naturall name of the thing meant, would ignifie. As to ay, Drops of Dew are Pearls; Flowers in Meadows are Starres, and the murmuring of waters, Muick; that little Birds are Angels of the Forrets; Whales are living Rocks, or Ships with ouls; that the Sea is a moving Earth; and fountain water, liquid Crytall. And in expreing Deirous; a kind of Deire, is thirt, and not much different from thirt is hunger; Therefore for words deirous of bloud, Sir Philip Sidney ays, hungry of bloud. Where you may note three degrees of a Metaphor in the undertanding; Firt, the fitnes to bloudhed in a weapon uurps the name of
Deirous, which is proper to a living Creature, and then that it proceeds to thirt, and o to hunger.

The rule of a Metaphor is, that it be not too bold nor too far fetch'd; And though all Metaphors go beyond the true ignification of things, yet are they requiite to expres the roving fancies of mens minds, which are not content to fix themelves upon one thing intended, but mut wander to the confines; Like the eye that cannot chue but view the whole knot, when it purpoely beholds but one flower in the Garden; Or like an Archer, that knowing his Bow will overcat or carry too hort, takes an aim on this ide or beyond the mark. Beides, a Metaphor is pleaant, becaue it enriches our knowledge with two things at once, with the Truth and a Similitude; As this, Heads diinherited of their naturall Seigniories, whereby we undertand both beheading, and the government of the head over the body, as the heir hath over the Lordhip, which he inherits; Of which in another place, To divorce the fair marriage of the Head and body; where beides the cutting off of the head, we undertand the conjunction of the head and body to reemble a marriage. The like in concealing love, uttered in thee words, To keep love cloe Prioner. There came along the treet a whole fleet of Coaches, for a great number. Longinus aith, That Metaphors and exchanges of words, are of excellent ue, and much conducing to height in eloquence.

An Allegory is the continuall proecuting of a Metaphor, (which before I defined to be, a tranlation of one word,) and that proportionably through the whole entence, or through many entences; As Philoclea was o invironed with weet Rivers of vertue, that he could neither be battered nor undermined: Where Philoclea is expreed by the imilitude
of a Catle; her naturall defence, by the naturall fortification of Rivers about a Catle; and the Metaphor continues in the attempting her by force or craft, expreed by battering or undermining. Another, But when he had once his Enign in her mind, then followed whole quadrons of longings, that o it might be with a main battle of milikings and repinings againt their Creation; where you have Enigns, Squadrons, main Battels; Metaphors till derived from the ame thing. i. Warr.

As I aid before, a Metaphor might be too bold, or too far fe • ch'd, o I now remember it may be too bae, and too bald a tranlation; As the Tempet of judgment had broken the main mat of his will. A goodly Audience of heep, Souldiers of friendhip, or uch like. Too bae, as in that peech, Fritter of fraud, and eething pot of iniquity. And they that ay, A Red herring is a hooing horn to a pot of Ale. But if you peak of didainfull • atter, you may ue the groer terms.

Therefore for generall delight, take your expreions from ingenious Arts and Profeions; to pleae the learned in everall kinds; As from the Meteors, Plants, Beats in naturall Philoophy; And from the Starres, Spheres and their motions in Atronomy; from the better part of Husbandry; from politick government of Cities; from Navigation, from the military profeion, from Phyick; but not out of the depth of thoe myteries; And (unles your purpoe be to diparage) let the word be always taken from a thing of equall or greater dignity, As peaking of Vertue, The skie of your vertue overcat with orrow, where 'twas thought unfit to toop to any Metaphor, lower then the Heaven.

An Embleme, an Allegory, a Simile, a Fable, a
Poeticall Fiction differ thus. An Embleme is but one part of the Similitude in the body and the other part under application in the words; An Allegory is the imilitude of the application expret indifferently, and joyned in one entence with words, ome proper to one part, ome to another; A Simile hath two entences of everall proper terms compared. A Fable is a Simile acted by Fictions in Beats; A Poets Tale, for the mot part by Gods and Men. In the former example, Paint a Catle, compat with Rivers, and let the Motto be NEC OBSIDIONE NEC CUNICULIS, Neither by iege nor undermining, that is an Embleme. Lay it as it is in Sir Philips Philoclea; Vertue, environed, Rivers, battering, undermining, the terms of the other part; Put all thee terms in one entence, and it is an Allegory; But let it be thus, There was a Lamb in a Catle, and an Elephant and a Fox beieged her; The Elephant would have aaulted her, but he could not wim over the River; the Fox would make an earth to get under her, but he feared the River would ink in upon him and drown him; then it is a Fable. Let Spencer tell you uch a Tale of a Fairy Queen, or Ovid of Danae, and 'tis a Poeticall Fiction: But utter it thus in one entence, As a Catle, compaed about with rivers, cannot be battered or undermined. (And thus in another) So Philoclea defended round about with vertuous reolution, could neither be forced nor urprized by deceit; Then it is a Similitude in its own nature, which is the ground of all Emblemes, Allegories, Fables and Fictions.

METONIMIA is an exchange of a name, when one word comes in lieu of another, not for a imilitude, but for other naturall affinity and coherence; As when the matter is ued for that which conits thereof; As, I want ilver, for money.
When the efficient or author is ued for the thing made; As my blade is right Sebatian; for, of Sebatians making. The thing containing, for the thing or peron contained; As the the City met the Generall, for the Citizens. The adjunct, property, or quality, for the ubject of it; As, deerts are preferred, for men deerving. Take heed young idlenes; for, idle youth. Give room to the quoif, for, the Serjeant; with the like.

SYNECDOCHE is an exchange of the name of the part for the whole, or of the name of the whole for the part. There are two kinds of totall comprehenions; An entire body, or a generall name; As, my name is toed and cenured by many to¯gues, for many men; where the part of an intire body goes for the whole. Contrariwie he carries a Goldmiths hop on his fingers, for Rings. He fell into the water and wallowed the Thames, for the water. So the generall name for the peciall; Put up your weapon, for your Dagger. And the peciall, for the particular, As, the Admirall is gone to ea, for Admirall Blake. The particular for the peciall. As I would willingly make you a Sir Philip Sidney, for an eloquent, learned, valiant Gentleman; or, for many; as, the Hollander they ay comes againt us, for the Hollanders, and uch like; which (becaue they are eaie) I have exemplified familiarly. Both thee figures erve well, when you have mentioned omthing before, that may require Variety in repetition.

CATACHRESIS, in Englih, Abue, is now grown in fahion, as mot abues are; It is omewhat more deperate then a Metaphor; And is the expreing of one matter by the name of another, which is incompatible with, and ometimes clean contrary to it; As, I gave order to ome ervants of mine, (whom I thought as apt for uch charities as my elf) to lead him out into a Forret, and there
kill him; where Charity is ued for Cruelty. But this may alo be by the Figure IRONIA. The abue of a word drawn from things far differing; As, a voyce beautiful to his ears. Accuing in himelf no great trouble in mind by his behaviour or action. Do you grudge me part of your orrow being iter in Nature, I would I were not o far off a Kin in fortune? This is a uuall figure with the fine converants of our time, when they train for extraordinary expreions; As I am in danger of preferment. I am not guilty of thoe praies. I have hardly ecaped good fortune. He threatens me a good turn. All by the contrary. And as he aid that miliked a picture with a crooked Noe. The elbow of his Noe is disproportionable.

The ear is not onely pleaed with tore and variety of words, but takes great delight in the repetition of the ame words; which, becaue they may be at the beginning, at the middle, in the end, and in undry correpondencies of each of thee places one to another; it happens that it has purchaed everall names of Figures; As Repetition of the ame word or ound immediatly without interpoition of any other, is called EPIZEUXIS. O let not, let not from you be powred upon me detruction. Tormented, tormented? torment of my oul, Philoclea tormented. This figure is not to be ued but in paion.

ANADIPLOSIS is a repetition in the end of a former entence, and beginning of the next; As, you fear let you hould offend; offend, O how know you that you hould offend? Becaue he doth deny, deny? now in earnet I could laugh, &c. Why loved I? alas, alas; why loved I? to die wretched, and to be the example of the heavens hate, and hate, pare not; for • our wort blow is given. — From whom they have commonly uch repect, and repect oon opens the door to
perwaion, &c. This figure is often and handomly ued by Sir William Davenant in his Preface to Gondibert. And as no man trikes in thought upon any thing, but for ome vehemency or ditrut; o in peech there is no repetition without importance.

CLIMAX is a kinde of ANADIPLOSIS, by degrees making the lat word a tep to a further meaning. If it be turned to an argument, it is a SORITES; A young man of great beauty, beautified with great honor, honored with great valor. You could not enjoy your goods, without government, no Government without a Magitrate, no Magitrate without obedience, and no obedience, where every one upon his private paion doth interpret the Rulers actions.

Now to make it a SORITES or climing argument, joyn the firt and the lat with an ERGO. As ERGO you cannot enjoy your own goods, where every man upon his own private paions doth, &c, This in a penned peech is too Academicall, but in dicoure more paable and plauible. Seeing to like, liking to love, loving to, &c. Deceived me, after deceit abued me, after abue foraken me. What doth better become widom then to dicern what is worthy loving? What more agreeable to goodnes then to love it, o dicerned? and what to greatnes of heart, then to be contant in it once loved. Where the lat word or ome one word in the lat entence begets the next claue. This Figure hath his time, when you are well entred into dicoure, have procured attention, mean to rie and amplifie.

ANAPHORA is when many claues have the like beginning; You whom vertue hath made the Princes of Felicity, be not the miniter of ruine. You whom my choyce hath made the Goddes of my afety. You whom Nature hath made the Load-tarr of comfort,
be not the rock of hipwrack. This figure beats upon one thing, to caue the quicker apprehenion of it in the audience, and to awake a leepy or dull paion.

EPISTROPHE is contrary to the former, when many claues end with the ame words; Where the richnes did invite the eyes, the fahion did en • ertain the eyes, and the device did teach the eyes. And all the night did nothing but weep. Philoclea, igh Philoclea, and cry out Philoclea, &c. Either arm their lives, or take away their lives. This is rather a Figure of Narration or Intruction, then of motion.

SIMPLOCE or COMPLEXIO, is when everall entences have the ame beginning and the ame ending. The mot covetous man longs not to get riches out of that ground which can bear nothing; Why? Becaue it is impoible. The mot ambitious peron vexes not his wits to climb to heaven. Why? becaue it is impoible. This is the wantonet of Repetitions, and is not to be ued in erious matters.

EPANALEPSIS is the ame in one entence which SIMPLOCE or COMPLEXIO is in everall; As, Severe to his ervants, to his children evere. Or the ame ound reiterated firt or lat in a entence. As, His uperior in means, in place his uperior. In orrow was I born, and mut die in orrow. nkindnes moved me, and what can o trouble my coures, or wrack my thoughts as unkindnes? This is a mild and weet Figure, and of much ue, though ingle and by it elf, not uuall in the Arcadia, unles thus, Overthrow of my deires, recompence of my overthrow.

EPANADOS is when the midt and the end, or the midt and the beginning are the ame, As, If there were any true pleaure in leep and idlenes, then
no doubt the Heathen Philoophers would have placed ome part of the felicity of their heathen Gods in leep and idlenes. Your diligence to peak well mut be great, but you hall be abundantly recompenced for the greatnes of your diligence in the ucces of perwaion. If I hould ever wih the perfection of your eloquence, it is for your intruction, and for your benefit, that I would wih you eloquent. This kind of Repetition and the former EPANALEPSIS are mot eaily admitted into dicoure, and are freet from the opinion of affectation; becaue words recited at the beginning of many entences, or at both ends of the ame, are more remarkable.

ANTIMETABOLE, or COMMUTATIO, is a entence invert, or turn'd back; as, If any for love of honor, or honor of love, &c. That as you are the child of a mother: o you may be mother of a child, &c. They miliked what themelves did; and yet till did what themelves miliked, &c. If before he languihed, becaue he could not obtain his deiring; he now lamented, becaue he could not deire the obtaining. — Either not triving, becaue he was contented; or contented, becaue he would not trive — Jut to exercie his might, mighty to exercie his jutice. Learned Sir Philip lipt often into this Figure, yet he ometimes conceald the particularity of his affection to it, by not turning the words wholly back, as they lay; To account it not a pure for treaure, but as a treaure it elf worthy to be purs'd up, &c. Men venture lives to conquer; he conquers lives without venturing, &c. Shewed uch fury in his force, uch tay in his fury; which is rather EPANADOS; Sometimes the ame ene invert in contrary words. As, Parthenia deir'd above all things to have Argalus; Argalus feared nothing but to mie Parthenia. Where he returns fear to mie in tead of deire.
Neither could you have thought o well of me, if extremity of love had not made your judgement partiall; nor could you have loved me o intirely, if you had not been apt to make o great undeerved judgment of me. Where he returns, for, extremity of love; loving intirely, and for partiall judgement; great undeerved judgement.

Though this be a harp and witty Figure, and hews out of the ame words, a pretty ditinction of meaning very convenient for Schoolmen, yet to •• e this or any other unreaonably or uneaonably, is ridiculous. Let dicretion therefore be the greatet, and mot generall Figure of Figures.

PARANOMASIA is a preent touch of the ame letter, yllable or word, with a different meaning. And as for the running upon the letter more then very little, is more then too much, Sir Philip Sidney in Atropell and Stella, calls it the Dictionary method, and veres o made, Rimes running in ratling rowes, which is is an example of it. There is an old Swinih Poem made of it in Latine, call'd PUGNA PORCORUM.

Agnomination of ome yllables is omtimes found in the Arcadia; as, Alas what can aying make them believe, whom eeing cannot perwade. And, while he was o followed by the valiantet, he made a way for the vilet. She went away repining, but not repenting. Our Alm-deeds are turned into all Mi-deeds; our praying into playing; our fating into feating. That kinde of breaking words into another meaning, is much
ed in Drolerie, and youthful Dicoure; as, you will have but a bare gain out of this bargain, A man not only fit for the gown, but for the gun; for the pen, but for the pike; for the book, but for the blade. The garnih of this figure hath been in much requet in les erious matters, but the more learned have avoided this kinde of flourih, let their writings hould avour more of the general humor, then of private judgement.

POLEPTOTON or TRADUCTIO, is a repetition of words of the ame linage, that differ only in termination; as, exceedingly, exceeding. His faulty uing of our faults. Sometimes the ame word in everal caes; as, for fear, conceal'd his fear. Sometimes the ame word in everal voyces; as, foraken by all friends, and foraken by all comfort. Sometimes the ame adjective in everal comparions; as, much may be aid in my defence, much more for love, and mot of all for that divine creature, who hath joyned me and love together. This is a good figure, and may be ued with or without paion, yet o as the ue of it come from choice, and not from barrennes.

To Amplifie and Illutrate, are two of the principal Ornaments of Eloquence, and gain mens mindes to the chiefet advantages, Admiration and Belief; For how can you commend any thing more acceptable to our Attention, then by telling us it is extraordinary, and by demontrating it to be evident. We love to look upon a Commet above all Stars, for thee two excellencies, its Greatnes and its Clearnes; uch in peech is Amplification and Illutration. We amplifie five ways, by Comparion, Diviion, Accumulation, Intimation, and Progreion.

Comparion is either of things contrary or equal,
or things different: Equal, as, Themito • les and Coriolanus (both great States-men, both of great deerts to their Countrey, both banihed, both dead at one t • me: Themitocles his Councel could not prevail against the Ingratitude of the Athenians; nor Coriolanus his Dicretion overcome the unkindenes of the Romans; the one was too excellent, the other too noble, for the envious eyes of their Countrymen to endure, uch is the force of vertue, above all quarrels of Nations, or diviions of Allegiances; that their exiles were honorably entertained, Coriolanus by the Volci, Themitocles by the Perians, both by their enemies, and both leading great Armies againt thoe Countreys, which o ingratefully expelled them) were o inwardly retrained with a concience of acking their native oil, that they rather choe violence to their own lives, then to the lives of their fellow Citizens, and took it for a ufficient revenge, to make it evident that they might be revenged. But this is not o forcible an Amplification of things equal indeed (wherein, as you ee, all the everal points of a conorted, equality are to be earched out), as when things eeming unequal are compared, and that in Similitudes, as well as in Examples; for intance, where a woman is compared to a hip, out of Plautus, both ask much tacking, and ometimes rigging: And you hall profit mot of all, by inventing matter of agreement in things mot unlike: London and the Tennis-Court are like: for in both all the gains go to th • hazard. Policy is like the Sea, it erves for intercoure of profit, for defence againt in • aions; the •• are both •• bings and flowings, calms and tempets; the obervation whereof may make a man firt wie, then rich. But as the water erves for many outward ues, o can it not pleae, if it be inwardly wa •• wed. If you • ail up • n it, it will carry you whereo'ere you will deire; but if you drink it, it doth
not atisfie, but increae deires. Again for Example; Eriphyle and Tarpeia (both women in whom nature hould govern love, and love warrant fidelity) were both eaily induced to be fale, with triffling temptations, they both betrayed, not one friend to another, nor the dearnes of love for the height of preferment, but their mot aured lovers to their mot deadly enemies, for toys, jewels and bracelets; Eriphyle, her husband Amphiaraus (the tay of her life) to Adratus, his profeed enemy: Tarpeia, the Capitol (the defence of her Country) to the Sabines, that beieged it, yet neither can remain as invitation, much les a encouragement to Treaon; For Eriphyle was lain by her on, whom nature hould have bound to her defence; Tarpeia by the Sabines, whom her deerts hould have obliged to her afe-guard. In comparing of two, when you would raie the peron or thing, which you intend to make excellent, you mut take the meanet parts of a greater example, and match them with the bet of your purpoe, and by uch partiality you hall amplifie and extol the ubject you treat of; as Iocrates did in his comparion of Cyrus and Thaagarus. Otherwie for impartial comparions, which notwithtanding do amplifie, read the matches, or encounters of the mot famous Grecian and Roman Examples in Plutark.

Comparions of things different. In the former Comparion, is a Compoition of the points at firt, becaue I preuppoe the hitories on both ides to be familiar unto you by reading; but if you were to marhal hitories, whereof both or either were not ufficiently known, then had you need to begin with ingle relations; As if a man would compare Vacus G • ma with Sir Francis Drake, he might ay, Sir Francis Drake indeed travelled round about the world in two years, aw divers Nations, endured
many perils at ea, and returned laden with great Treaure; And Vacus Gama firt earched the Coat of Quiloa, Mozambique, and Calicute, and opened the paage to the Eat-Indies. But as it was eaie for Drake to proceed further in dicoveries, when he had entrance made by Columbus: So was it mot dangerous and difficult for Gama to adventure a coure, without example and direction: Drake coured the Coats with a ufficient company of hips, made pillage of others, and thereof furnihed himelf for his interprize; Gama went but weak at firt, lot mot of his mall Fleet, and met nothing at eas, but tempets and famine. Drake invaded upon opportunities, hazarded but his own fortune, and retired to ea upon all advantages: Gama had in charge an expedition of his Soveraigns Commandment, was contrained to victual himelf amongt barbarous Nations, and not only buy proviion in their continent with the price of his blood, but durt not depart without leaving his King proclaimed and poeed in their Territories, divers places of trength fortified, and etablihed to his ue: So that if Gama had been to purue the example of Drake, as Drake had the light of Columbus and Magellus Travels, Vacus Gama's pirit was as like to have conquered the whole world, as Drakes fortune was to compas it. And where the parts of Collation are mot obcure, there your narration mut be the longer; As, Cicero in comparing Marcellus and Verres, makes a long recitall of the acts of Marcellus to acquaint the hearers with them before comparion. In ome caes, after good confidence of proof, your examples may come in more thick and plentiful; As, If to protract a battell upon advice, be cowardize, then Ph • cion, then Metellus, then Fabius, and all the valiantet Captains of all ages were cowards. If to diplant the rebellious natives of Scotland, and to root them out of that kingdom, be cruelty,
then the Colonies tranlated by the Romans into Sicily, into France, into the everall coats of Italy, & divers other places, testifie great cruelty. But comparion of things different is mot commendable, where there eems to be great affinity in the matters conferred; As in the King of Spains aiting the Irih, and the Queen of Englands aiding the Netherlands. The Spaniard gave aitance to a people untrue in their Treaties, uncivill in their manners, to thoe who have traiterouly rebelled without provocation, and fled out contrary to their own ubmiion, brake their own peace, and wated their own Countrey. The Queen did but lend ome few voluntaries to the protection of a Nation, peaceable in their lives, free by their priviledges, a people denying no claim of any true Prince, except perpetual ervitude of their bodies, and importable exactions of their goods. Another example of things different compared. Is not the marriage of heads of Houes & Colledges as lawful as the marriage of the Doctors of the Arches, or the Clerks of the Chancery, both were interdicted by the ame law, & yet I take it not indifferent, that both hould by the abrogation of the ame Law be equally repealed; The one hath his living cauall by his temporall pains, the other his maintenance certain by Eccleiatical proviion; The one may purchae by the improving his revenues, & o may lawfully raie a patrimony to maintain his poterity: The other can by no thrift upon the common goods, gather a living for a wife and children, without imbezeling from the poor, deducting from Hopitality, defeating the intent of the giver, or defrauding his ucceion. Latly, the one hath all to the ue of his office, the other is owner of nothing, but to his own behoof and dipoition. In thee two orts of Amplifications you may inert all Figures, as the paion of the matter hall erve.

Comparion of contraries is the third and mot flourihing way of Comparion. Contraries are omtimes
arranged together by pairs one to one, thus. Compare the ones impatiency with the others mildnes, the ones inolency with the others ubmiion, the ones humility with the others indignation, and tell me whether he that conquered eemed not rather confounded, then he that • yeelded any thing dicouraged. Compare not mind with mind let it eem fantaticall, and beyond the triall of our enes; But et the ones triumph againt the others captivity, los againt victory, feats againt wounds, a Crown againt fetters, misfortune againt felicity, & the majety of courage will be found in the overthrown. More examples of this you have in the figure Contentio, which is one of the intruments to aggravate, by way of Comparion. Yet one example more. He that prefers wealthy ignorance before chargeable tudy, prefers contempt before honor, darknes before light, death before life, and earth before, heaven.
This is one way of arranging contrarieties.

There is another way of ordering them with interchangeable correpondence in entences, that though each touch not other, yet it affronts the other: As, Shall a Souldier (for a blow with his hand given in warr to a Captain) be digraced? And hall a Lawyer (for the Batinado given in a Court of Jutice to his companion) be advanced? hall we that profes Laws, maintain outrage? And hall they that break all Laws, yet in this oberve civility? Where you may ee every word in the later entence aggravated by oppoition to every word in the former. Another, Did the mot innocent vouchafe a part of his glory to pray for his enemies? And hall we the mot infull eteem it a blot to our reputation to be unrevenged on our brethren? Of this you hall have more examples hereafter. But unles it be for the Declamatory exercie, you are to avoyd too great welling without ubtance.

The econd way of Amplification, is by Diviion, which (as a modern Author ays) is to anatomize it into everall parts, and to examine it according to everall circumtances; Not unlike the hew that Pedlers make of their Packs when they diplay them, contrary to the German magnificence, that erves in all the good meat in one dih. But whereas the ame Author ays, that this Art of Amplifying will betray it elf in method and order. I think it rather adorns it elf. For in tead of aying, He put the whole Law to the Sword; let me reckon all ages and orts, and ay; He neither aved the young men, as pittying the unripe flower of their youth; nor aged men, as repecting their gravity; nor children, as pardoning their weaknes; nor women, as having compaion on their Sex; Souldier, Clergyman, Citizen; armed or unarmed, reiting or ubmitting, all within the Town were detroyed by the fury of that bloody Executioner. Note that the diviions here, are taken from age, profeion, ex, habit, or behaviour. It may likewie be from all circumtances; All dance, the Heavens, Elements, mens mindes, Common-wealths, and o by part all dance.

Another example varied, He apparels himelfe with great dicretion; Thus amplifie for circumtances, For tuffs, His cloathes were more rich then glittering: As to the fahion, rather uuall for his ort, then fantatical for his invention; for colour, more grave and uniform then wild and light. For fitnes, made as well for eae of exercie, as to et forth to the eye thoe parts which had in him any excellency. So, to ay, he would take an occaion of dicoure with a young witty Lady, and would raie it firt from her behaviour. If he aid nothing he would partly quarrell with her ilence; if he miled, he would gather out of it ome interpretation of praie of her
favour, and of his own joy and good fortune; if he frowned, he would both move her to mirth, and deny that he could be angry in earnet; if he were ad, he would conform his peech and action in that obernes to her humor, as might beguile her paion, by way of fale confederacy; if he walked or played, the ecret praie of her face, her eyes, her hair, her voyce, her hands, her body, her gait, was the application of mot conceipts, whatever gave the ground of them; yet with uch diembling art, as if forgetfulnes or love alluded in them, not cunning or want of variety.

So you may divide by the forms of peech in general; as, he was never to eek how to propoe or invent, raie or maintain, reconcile and ditinguih any Arguments, Hitories, Similitudes, Proverbs; Jets attended him in great plenty, when he needed to imploy them: he would deliver trong Reaons carelely, and choyce words moothly and unaffectedly; he ued a porting widom, an eloquent prating. But with Gallants and Ladies of better repect, and les curioity, his duty, their kindenes, their common acquaintance, the occaion of his coming, the remembrance of his lat conference, the place, the time, the lat news of forraign parts, the Court, the Countrey, the City, fed his invention, and atisfied their ears. All this is but diviion of the perons, with whom you convered, their Manners, Carriage, the Fahions and Ornaments, the Matter and Subject of dicoure. This in ome ort ued, is more properly called Dilatation, then Amplification; and being often practied, will inable you to dicoure almot of any thing, wherein you are not preciely tyed to the exact manner of diviion, which Logicians ue. But you have liberty of eeking all things comprized within the ence of your generall Theame, differ they eentially, or in any notable
Property. You may alo if you pleae, run over the intire part of Amplification; as, the hip was blown up; for the hip you may ay the mat, ails, tacklings, keel, prowe, tern; for blowing up, you may ay rent, torn, mouthered, cattered in the ayr, unk under the water, all the circumtances of blowing up. So in aying a fair tree, you may divide the tree into the root, body, branches and fruit; and fairnes, into talnes, traitnes, verdure, weetnes, and uch things as are fair in a tree. In decribing a gallant man, you may talk of his minde, peron, his attempting, proecuting and finihing an enterprize. And note, that this Amplification hath in it both credibility and intruction; for it makes intances of that which being generally poken, would eem but a flourih, and gives more pecial note of that kinde, which univerally could not be conceived, without confuion and dulnes. This kinde of Amplification is more taken up by Cicero then Demothenes; for Demothenes never ues it, but as it falls in his way.

The third way of Amplification, is Accumulation, which is a heaping up of many terms of praie or accuation, importing but the ame matter, without decending into any part, and hath his due eaon after ome argument of proof. Otherwie it is like a Schoolman foming out Synonima's, or words of one meaning, and will ooner beget a cenure of uperfluity of words, then of ufficiency, of matter. But let us give ome example to amplifie a Sedition; tumults, mutinies, uproars, deperate conpiracies, wicked confederacies, furious commotions, trayterous rebellions, aociations in villany, ditractions from allegiance, bloody garboyles, intetine Maacres of Citizens. But this example is omewhat too welling. Now to decribe a beautiful woman; you may ay, She hath a
mot winning countenance, a mot pleaant eye, a mot amiable preence, a cheerful apect, he is a mot delicate object, &c. The tate of former times hath termed it weet, to bring in three claues together of the ame ene; as, Your beauty (weet Lady) hath conquered my reaon, ubdued my will, matered my judgement. How this will hold amongt our curious ucceors in their time, I know not; he that looks on the wearing of it, will finde it bare, how full of tuff oever it appears. Firt, it paeth for parts of diviion, when indeed it is but a variation of an Englih. Yet notwithtanding the practie will furnih you tore of phraes, without which you hal never have choyce, the Mother of perfection. Cicero in his Orations ues it much; ome others follow it to four claues, but he eldom exceeds three. It has this certain effect, that it will ufficiently ecure your vein not to be dry and exhauted. But to return to our firt ort of Accumulation, and reduce it with this under one precept. I take the ue of this to be in anger, detetation, commieration, and uch paions, as you, eeming throughly poet with, would willingly tir up in others.

The fourth way of Amplification is by Intimation, and leaves the collection of greatnes to our undertanding, by expreing ome mark of it. It exceeds peech in ilence, and makes our meaning more intelligible by a touch, then by direct treating; as he that hould ay, you mut live very many years in his company, whom you hould account for your friend, ays well; but he that ays, you had need eat a buhel of alt with him, aith more, and gives you to reckon more then many years in his company, whom you hould account for your friend. It avours ometimes of Hyperbole; as, that man that is grown gros, is grown from a body to a corporation; again, for a little man on
hore back, He was taken for a hat riding on the pommel of a addle. Of this ort, examples are familiar; So honet a wrangler, that his noe being betwixt, was the onely caue why his two eys went not to Law. So the hugenes of a Gyant is expret, by aying, his skull held half a buhel of wheat. This may be done with Ironia, or denyal. He was no notorios malefactor, but he had been twice on the pillory, and once burnt in the hand for trifling overights. So, by ambiguity of the word, he draws his word oftner then his pure. This fahion of Amplification, I term Intimation, becaue it doth not directly aggravate; but by conequence or proportion, intimate more to your minde, then to your ears.

PROGRESSIO is the lat kinde of Amplification, which by teps of comparion corns every degree, till it come to the upreme; and ometimes to advance the matter higher, it decends lower. It is an ornament in peech to begin at the lowet, that you may apire to the highet Amplification. For example, in reprehending the prodigality of Monuments. I begin with the excees of Alphonus on his fathers funeral; thence to Alexanders profuion upon one of his friends Tombs; then to Urbanus, towards his ervant; thence to Caear, on his hores burial; after that, to the Moloians on their dogs; and thence to the Egyptians, that charged themelves with the umptuous burial of a Crocodil. So eeming in ome ort, to admit the firt les then the econd, and by growing weaker and weaker in the exces of every one, as I proceed, the lat will eem mot rediculous, if not odious. So Cicero againt Verres meaning to amplifie his Bribery and Extortions. It is rigorous exaction (aith he) not to abolve the innocent without money; great cruelty to commit him, till be ranom himelf; but not to uffer the parties to have
acces unto him without reward, is wretched covetounes. To ell the egres and regres of them that hall bring him victuals; nay, to take money that he hall have an eaie death: To put a price upon the trokes that hall execute him; So much, that he hall be beheaded at one blow; o much, at two. This is beyond all degrees of mot barbarous and intollerable extortion. So in another example; He was careles of doing well, a loones of youth; he was inclined to do ill, a weaknes of fleh; his minde conented to offend, a hrewd temptation; he committed the act, an unhappy fault; he accutomed himelf to abue, a ad employment: yet he did not this alone, but infected others with his perwaion, and educed them by his example. And not that only, but detained thoe he had drawn in, with freh inventions, and digraced the modety of them who reited his corruptions, with corns and deriions, which could argue no les in him, then a mot reprobate damnable reolution.

The rule of this is, when you would praie or dicommend any thing, to conider how many les things there are of that kinde, to which notwithtanding you would give ome hew of importance. As he that would render leep obnoxious, may ay that Idlenes (which is les) by Draco's Laws was Felony. Or, to give that Bihop his right, that built two abolute Colledges at his own charges, and indowed them with Lands. Look downwards how rare it is for a Prelate in thee days, not to grant long Leaes, diminih the revenues of his fee. How laudable it is to repair the ruines of his own decayed Palaces and Granges? How magnificent an Act it is thought for a noble man to build an Hopital. How royal for two or three Princes to erect one Colledge. And can there be uch an unthankfulnes, as to bear but an ordinary remembrance of him, that inricht his Bihoprick,
built two the mot famous Nureries of Learning in the Land, was liberal to all wants in his life, and left worthy bequets to all degrees at his death. In like ort, by an example of abuing the name of God. To make table talk of a mean mans name were injurious; to run upon a Noble mans title, were great candal; to play with a Princes name, were Treaon: And what hall it be to make a vanity of that name, which is mot terrible even to Tyrants and Devils, and mot reverend even to Monarchs and Angels? There be two contrary acents to the top of this form, either by extenuating the means, as in a former example: or by aggravating them, as in this lat of wearing. And may not a matter be well amplified in this manner, by exchanging the comparion of every particular circumtance, that the whole may eem the greater? As in this example, It is lamentable that a yong man hould be offended with the advice of his experienced friend, tending to his profit. Firt, it is a hard cae that counel hould be neglected, but harder that it hould offend. It is a ad thing to ee any dipleaed with good admonitions, but more ad, to ee a youth o affected, Who would not grieve to have his advice ill taken? but who would not grieve more, to ee his experience controlled? nhappy is that youth, that litens not to the good exhortations of the Skilful. But more, that didains the intructions of his dicreet friend. He is mierable and unfortunate, that quarrels with the ound precepts of his dear friends; but more mierable and unfortunate, that milikes directions given for his own good and advantage.

This is a mot eaie, clear and uual kinde of Amplification; For it gives more light and force to every circumtance. The circumtances are thee. The perons, who and to whom, the matter, the intent, the time, the place, the manner, the conequence,
and many more: Out of every one of which, any thing may be made more notable, and egregious by way of comparion. And that it may the better be remembred by you, let inquiry be made in every controveri • for the circumtances, and compare them with other les matters, and you hall hardly fail of dicoure, or be left on ground for want of good invention. There is a richer hew in this kinde of amplifying by every circumtance, then in any other. Firt, you mut begin every circumtance with a new figure. Sometimes with Affirmation, ometimes with Interrogation, ometimes with Admiion, ometimes with Ironia. Secondly, when you, upon every circumtance, urge the whole ene, you are for every circumtance almot to vary the words: As before, for Lamentable; unhappy, unfortunate, heavy, ad, grievous; o for Counel; A • monitions, Advice, Exhortations, Intructions, Precepts, Directions. Again, I ay, remember this kinde of Progreion by circumtances, and urging and aggravating all the points of a Sentence: For you hall finde it ued as much as any figure in Rhetorique, by all good Speakers and Writers.

There are Figures that help Amplification, and make hew of etting forth a matter fairer then it is. The firt of them is HIPERBOLE, whereof I will give you ome uch examples, as my own reading long ince oberved in the Arcadia. Sometimes it expreeth a thing in the highet degree of poibility beyond the truth, that in decending thence, you may finde the truth. Sometimes in flat impoibilities, that you may rather conceive the unpeakablenes, then the untruth of the relation. Poibly, as for Hypocritical Hote; he gave as pleaing entertainment, as the falet heart could give him, whom he means wort unto. That ever eye aw, or heart could imagine. For
diligent inquiry; making their eyes, their ears, and their tongue erve for nothing ele, but for that inquiry. This is the utmot that is poible. But in the very frontiers of impoibility, thus, though a thouand deaths followed it, and every death were followed with an hundred dihonors. The world ooner wanted occaions, then he valour to go through them. Words and blows came o thick together, as the one eemed a lightning to the others thunder. Sometimes there is no certain quantity of a thing et, but plainly and ingeniouly told unvariably. As, Beyond the bounds of conceipt, much more of utterance. And, this Figure is more for the credit of your wit, then of your peech.

CORRECTIO, having ued a word of ufficient force, yet pretending a greater trength of meaning, refues it, and upplyes the place with one of more extenion; as, I perwade you not to let lip occaion, whilt it may not onely be taken, but offers, nay ues to be taken. Where the firt riing of the matter is, upon, Not onely, but, then upon the correcting, Nay: Again, you mut be content, nay you mut be deirous to take pains, if you will write well; It is the onely quality, which in all actions will gain you praie, praie (aid I,) nay honor. This Figure is to be ued, when you would make the matter more credible in it elf, then by the manner of delivery; 'tis ometimes ued upon paion, without intent to amplifie. As, you tars, if you do not uccor me: no, no, you will not help me. O Parthenia, no more Parthenia, what art thou? There are two contrary ways to this form, and both lead to Amplification, but in a diembling ort. The firt is by Ironia, which exprees a thing by the contrary, by hew of exhortation, where indeed it dehorteth. As, yet a while, leep a while, fold thine arms a while: o hall neceity overtake thee, like a traveller, and poverty
et on thee like an armed man. It was but mall charges of idle money that the Egyptians betowed in erecting of a Pyramis of Brick, when the expences in Onyons and garlike for Workmens dyet, came to about 238000 l. of our money. Milo had but lender trength, that carryed an Ox a furlong on his back, then killed him with his fit, and eat him to his Breakfat. Titornus had a reaonable good arm; that could hold two bulls by the tails, the one in the one hand, and the other in the other, and never be tirred out of his place by their violence. Here mall, lender and reaonable, amplifie as much as if you had aid great, exceeding, or in • redible.

Paralepis (the econd counterfeit of Amplification) is when you ay you let pas that which not withtanding you touch at full: as, I make no account of any hinderance in other the direct tudies of my coure: I value not my pains in collecting thee Obervations. I will forget that I denyed the earnet intreaty of many kinde and learned Gentlemen, that ued to me for helps: I am loath to tell you they are notes of his whom your Maters of the niverity have thought as great a Reader, and a greater oberver, then themelves; I deire not, that you hould make any greater etimation of them, then of a tetimony of my love to you, and a pledge of my reolution to encourage thoe lovely parks of good invention, which if you mother and quench in your elf, you commit a kinde of intellectual murther. The like is ued often in Progreion. But an other, I urge not to you the hope of your friends, though that hould animate you to anwer their expectation, I lay not before you the neceity of the place, which you are to furnih, wherein to be defective and inufficient were ome hame; I omit the envious concurrencies, and ome prepared comparions in your Countrey, which have ome feeling with yong men of fore-ight; I onely ay, how hall our promies give judgement againt us? how
hall we dicharge our own Engagements to your Father, if this time hath not taken his full effect of profit in our labours and endeavors. Two figures properly belong to this kinde of Amplification, which are called Accumulation and Diviion.

The firt is a round dipatching of much matter, not plainly and imply the ame in ene, yet tending to the ame end; as, Loves companions be unquietnes, longings, fond comforts, faint dicomforts, hopes, jealouies, rages, carelenes, yieldings, &c. Spite, rage, didain, hame, revenge came upon hatred. Thee examples are out of Arcadia. You may frame one thus, All men exclaim upon thee exactions, Nobles, Gentry, Commonalty; Poor, Rich, Schollers, Merchants, Peaants, Yong, Old, High, Low, and all cry out upon the hard impoitions of thee burthens.

The econd Figure differs not much from the firt, but that the firt is a udden entrance into a confued heap of matter: This is a wilde and diolute repetition of all that went before. As, you have heard of his pride, ambition, cozenage, robberies, mutinies, in the City, in the Camp, in the Country. What kinman of his unabued, what friend undeceived, what companion uncorrupted, can peak for him? where can he live without hame? where can he dye with honor? Thee two Figures do not only make your caue eem better, but skilfully and properly ued, do amaze an adverary of mean ability.
There are other Figures that come in fitly after Amplification or any great heat jutly i • flamed, Interrogation and Exclamation.

Interrogation is but a warm propoition, yet it oftentimes doth better then a bare Affirmation, which were but too eaie and live-les a peech: as, The credit of behaviour, is to cover imperfection, and et forth your good parts better. Thus expreed, Is it
not the chiefet credit of behaviour, to et forth your good parts fairly and clearly, and to cover imperfection. Men are ignorant, and therefore by good expreions without raunting or affectation, you hall gain a more general opinion, then by ufficiency mothered in too modet a ilence. By Interrogation thus, Are not mot men ignorant? hall you not then by quaint expreions, withoutraunting or affectation, pleae more, and get a more general good opinion, then by great ufficiency concealed by your own hamefatnes? To diemble excellencies is good policy in him, whom his coure mut at length necearily draw into light and proof, and then all that he delivers will be admirable, becaue expectation foretall'd nothing of his worth; which may likewie be turned into an Interrogation, and is very fit for a peech, addreed to many illiterate hearers; is much ued in Pirocles Oration to the editious multitude, and then it may be well frequented and iterated. Did the Sun ever bring fruitful Harvet; but was more hot then pleaant? Have you any of your children, that be not ometimes cumberom? Have you any Fathers that be not ometimes froward? hall we therefore cure the Sun? hate our children? and diobey our Fathers? An example of many Interrogations. Have you not een a tately kinde of courteie, and a proud kinde of humility? have you not een a wie man withdraw himelf from mean company, with better grace, and more kindenes, then ome illy Gentleman that has betowed himelf on fools, thrown himelf down into the midt of his mieries? doth not a commendations, a hat, a good word, a good-morrow, p • rchae more hearts then a moneths familiar pratling; with a flock of rude people? Do you convere with your uperiors, to learn of them to be able to judge them, and benefit your elf? And hall not your inferiours do the like with you? Is it not a afer gain of popularity, with
ceremonies, then with dicovering your Nature? Many uch like Interrogations might be added; but let it uffice, that it is eaie and gentile to harpen the flats of affirmations and down-right telling of Tales.

EXCLAMATION is not lawful, but in the extremity of motion; as Pyrocles, eeing the mild Philoclea innocently beheaded, cryed out, O Tyrant Heaven, and Traytor Earth, blind Providence, how is this done? How is this uffered? Hath this world a Government? The like in the beginning of the econd book of the Arcadia in the peron of Ginetia tormented in mind. O Sun! O Heavens! O Deerts! O Vertue! O imperfect proportion! And in another Author thus; O endles endeavour! O vainglorious Ignorance! Dot thou deire to be known? Where? In Europe, how cant thou be famous? When Aia and Africa, that have thrice as many people, hear not of thy actions? Art not thou then thrice as obcure as thou art renowned? Dot thou look that all the world hould take notice of thee, when for five thouand years three parts of the world took no notice of the fourth. But Europe is the houe of Fame, beca • e it is the Nurery of Arts, and Books, wherein reports are preerved. O weak imagination! O elf-pleaing fancy! Cant thou expect in thee parts from 40 degrees to 90 Northward, uch praies and honours for thy name, when every Map on every wall hews thee as much pace from 40 to 90 Southward, inhabited with nothing but ilence and forgetfulnes.

ACCLAMATION is a ententious claue of a dicoure, or a report, uch as Daniel in his Poems concludes with often. It is a generall intruction for every man commonly for his pains in reading a Hitory, or other mens Books for ome privat ue of it to himelf. Like a Cah-keeper, who
drawing great ums of other mens money, challenges omwhat in the pound for his own Fee. It erves for Amplification, when after a great crime or Deert exclaim'd upon, or extol'd, it gives a morall note worth credit and obervation. As after the true relation of Scipio Africanus's coure, who having been chief governor of the greatet Armies in the world; having all his life time Kings uiters for his favour, and nations kept in awe of his Name; yet in 56 years neither bought nor old goods or lands, built any Houe or Catle of his own, left not above 46. l. in Gold, and 6. l. in ilver behind him at his death. It may be folded up in this Acclamation: So little need has he to toop to privat cares, that thrives upon publick victories; and o mall leaure has he to be deirous of riches, that hath been o long poet and atisfied with honor, which is the immortall end of mortal actions. Such notes are th • e craps of policy which ome now-a-days gather out of Polybius and Tacitus, and not unlike are the Morals that hang upon Eops Fables.

This Acclamation ometimes is the caue and reaon of a former Narration, as a tory of one, who being a ervant to a family, and of mean quality, won the doting love of a witty Lady in the Houe, whereas he never looked upon the humble uits, the cunning ininuations, the noble deerts of many lovers of higher degree, but with free judgment and careles cenure; This cloe may follow, So hard entrance hath affection into a heart prepared to upition, epecially in the weaket natures, whoe afeguard is mitrut: So eaie is the increae of love by inenible teps, when the ervice you offer eems to proceed out of the goodnes of your own dipoition, which women expect to be permanent, and not out of the neceity of your uit, which may force you for the time to a wained difference
from the proper humor. Yet if this be too much ued, it is like a note-book gathered out of Hitories.

Contrary to Amplification is DIMINUTION, and this decends by the ame teps that Amplification acends, and differs no more then up Hill and down Dale, which is the ame way, begun out of everall entences; Yet ome examples in Arcadia, will make you oberve two ways of Diminihing ingle terms, one by denying the contrary; As if you hould ay, But reaonably pleaant; Arcadia peech is, Not unpleaant, hardly liked, nor miliked. But why hould I give examples of the mot uuall phraes in the Englih tongue, as we ay, Not the wiet that ever we aw, for a man of mall widome. The econd way is, by denying the right of the words, but by error of ome; As, Thoe fantaticall mind-infected people, which Children and Muicians call Lovers. That misfortune of letting fall his Dagger, which the rude Swaggerers of our time, call, being diarmed. That opinion of honety, which hath lately been o proudly tranlated by the Souldier into the word (Honor.) And uch like. But the former fahion of Diminution ometimes in Ironious ort goes for Amplification, As peaking of a great peronage, No mean man; This is an ordinary Figure for all kinds of peeches.

The Figures following erve for Amplification.
< in non-Latin alphabet > is a compoition of contraries, and by both words intimates the meaning of neither preciely, but a moderation and mediocrity, As, bravery and raggery are contrary, yet omwhat better then both is meant by brave raggednes. So, wanton modety; inticing obernes. And with that he prettily miled, which mingled with tears, a man could not tell, whether it were a mourning pleaure, or delightfull
orrow. With what a witty ignorance he would undertand? &c. Abented preence; well-willing pight. The one contrary is aff • rmed to be in the other directly, by making the one the Subtantive, the other the Adjective, as above in thoe examples; or indirectly, as in thee words following. Seeking Honor by dihonor; And building afety upon ruine; O foolih woman, and mot mierable foolih woman, becaue wit makes thee foolih. Captivity might eem to have authority over tyranny. This is a gentile way to move admiration in the hearers, and make them think it a trange harmony, which mut be expret in uch dicord. Therefore this example hall conclude. There was a perfect agreement in o perfect a diagreement: like muick made of cunning dicords. This is an eaie Figure, and ueful.

CONTENTIO is contrary to the former; That was a compoition of Sturmius diagreement; This is an oppoition of them. As, there was trength againt nimblenes, rage againt reolution, pride againt noblenes. He is a waggerer amongst quiet men? but is quiet among swaggerers? Earnet in idle things, idle in matters of earnetnes. Where there is both Antimetabole for the turning of the entence back, and Contentio repecting the contra
• iety of things meant thereby. Could not look on, nor would not look off. Neither the one hurt her, nor the other help her. Jut without partiality, humble without contradiction, Liberall without profuion, Wie without curioity. This Figure is fit to embelih a copious tile, and erves much for Amplification by Comparion.

COMPAR is an even gait of entences anwering each other in meaures interchangeably. Such as are in St. Augutine often, but oftner in Gregory the Divine; And in Bihop Andrews works in
Englih. But many do intermingle this Figure with Agnominatio, and Similiter cadens; It is very uefull in elocution; But in penning it mut be ued with modes • y and mediocrity. A touch of Agnomination of the Letter is tollerable with a Compar; As, If ever I could wih my Faith untryed and my Councel untruted. And (where there is a imiliter cadens, but a more evident falling alike) in this. My years are not o many, but that one death may conclude them; nor my faults o many, but that one death may atisfie them. Without cononancy of fall or harping upon a letter or yllable, yet a Compar; becaue the words match each other in rank. Save his gray hairs from rebuke, and his aged mind from depair; where gray hairs, aged mind, rebuke and depair anwer each other. Again, Rather eek to obtain that contantly by courteie, which you cannot auredly enjoy by violence. Verb to Verb, Adverb, to Adverb, and Subtantive to Subtantive. Lovelines can neither warrant you from upitions in others, nor defend you from melancholy in your elf. In ome places there is a horter Compar: where word to word, or ubtantive to ubtantive, are joyned, and yet without conjunction, which is ASYNDETON. Her face with beauty, her head with widom, her eyes with Majety, her countenance with gracefulnes, her lips with louelines; Where many (Ands) are pared. In ome places only the Conjunction is put in the lat in a Compar of three; As, her wit endeared by youth, her afction by birth, and her adnes by her beauty. A fair woman hal not onely command without intreaty, but perwade without peaking. This is an excellent Figure, in no place untimely, if not too often ued; It fits well the even paues and interruptions of an eloquent tongue, eems to be rich and copious,
and to contain many parts (whereof each with a tedious man would be a entence) and make an impreion upon the hearers enes; It has long bin in requet, ever ince the dayes of Iocrates, whoe Orations are full of it. This Figure belongs more properly to that part of Amplification, called Diviion, then to Accumulation.

Sententia, if it be well ued, is a Figure; if ill and too much, a Style, of which none that wri • e humorouly and factiouly, can be clear in thee days, when there are o many Schimes of Eloquence, We tudy now-a-days according to the predominancy of Criticall fancies. Whil • t Moral Philoophy was in requet, it was rudenes, not to be ententious; whilt Mathematicks were of late in vogue, all imilitudes came from Lines, Circles and Angles; But now that Mars is predominant, we mut recruit our wits, and give our words a new Quarter. It is very true, that a Sentence is a pearl in a Dicoure; but it is a good Dicoure that conits all of pearls. It is like an Eye in the body, nor is it montrous to be all Eys. I take Cyclops to be as handome a man, as Argos. And if a Sentence were as like a hand in the Text, as it is commonly noted with a hand in the Margent, yet I hould rather like that work that had no more hands then Hercules, then that which had as many as Briarius.

Thee are Sentences, The rich mans bounty is the poor mans Exchequer. The icknes of age is avarice; The errors of youth profanenes. There is mall difference between a Propoition and a Quetion, if I forget not Aritotle. (1. Top.) Since length of acquaintance, mutual ecreies, nor height of benefits could oblige a avage mind. There is a Sentence, and in it ZEUGMA, ASYNDETON, and METAPHORA.
Guiltlenes is not always with eae oppreed, Where there is Meriois, not always with eae, for, ever and hardly. Who tands onely upon defence, tands upon no defence; A entence with EPANADOS. nlawfull deires are punihed after the effect of enjoying; But impoible deires are punihed in the deire it elf. A Sentence with DISTINCTIO and CONTENTIO. Love to a yeilding heart is a King, but to a reiting, a Tyrant. COMPAR & CONTENTIO; It is a foolih wittines to peak of more then one thinks. Neither is this entence without a Compar: it is a double entence, as they call it; To a heart fully reolved, counel is tedious, and reprehenion loathome. And, There is nothing more terrible to a guilty heart, then the eye of a repected friend. There may be alo Sentences particular to ome men as well as generall; As, — Amphialus, in whom abued kindnes became pitefull rage. Fearfulnes, contrary to all other vices, making Clinias think the better of another, the wore he found himelf. Evarchus making his life the example of his lawes. All which may be taken for Rules and Common-places, by putting the generall name for the peciall, as they ay, drawing it à THESI ad HYPOTHESIN. Thee Examples may make you believe, that a Sentence may be cours'd through the whole Figure-book, and that many Figures may eaily aemble in one Claue, and any one Figure conort with another. Yet it were aburd to ground the form and fahion of your whole tile upon any one Figure.

ILLUSTRATION conits either in things or words, in the decription of things living or dead. And of living things, either reaonable, as men and their peronages, and qualities; or un
• e • ona • le, as of Hores, Ships, Ilands, Catles,
and uch like. Men are decribed mot excellently in the Arcadia, As Bailius, Plexe • tus, Pirocles, Muidorus, Anaxius, &c. But he that will truly characterize a • an, in a feigned Story, mut firt learn handomly to decribe a humour, a paion, a vertue, a vice, and therein, keeping decent proportion, add but names, and knit together the accidents and encounters. This perfect expreing of all qualities, is learn'd out of Aritotles tenth Book of Morall Philoophy. But becaue (as Mac • iavel oberves) perfect vertue, or perfect vice is not een in our time, which altogether is humorous and pirting: Therefore the undertanding of Aritotles Rhetorique is held to be the bet means to attain to true Eloquence; Excellent on this ubject alo are Theophrati imagines; Heliodorus and Longinus in Greek (the lat lately well tranlated into Englih) Zanaxarus his Arcadia in Italian, Diana de monte majori in Spanih, &c. But to our purpoe, of peronages and affections decribed in Arcadia. For men; pleaant, idle retirednes in a King Bailius, and a dangerous end of it. Unfortunate valor in Plangus; Courteous valor in Amphialus; Proud valor in Anaxius; Hopitality in Kalandar; The mirror of true courage and friendhip in Pirocles, and Muidorus; Mierablenes and ingratitude in Chremes; Fear and fale ubtilty in Clynias; Fear and rudenes, with ill affected civility in Dametas; And through this Story Mutuall love in marriage in Argalus and Parthenia; O • t of marriage in Pirocles and Philoclea, Muidorus and Pamela, True contant love unrepected in Plangus, in Helena, in the true Zelmane; Incontancy, envy, upition and tyranny in a King and his Councellors; Generall fale love in Phamphilus; and light carriage and credulity in Chremes
daughter; bae doting on a wife in Plangus father. But in women a michievous and editious tomack in Cecropia; Prudent courage in Pamela; Mild dicretion in Philoclea • ; Pamela's prayer, her dicoure, queamih cunning; Unworthines in Arteia; Repective & retles dotage in Gynetia's love. Proud ill-favoured, luttih implicity in Mopa. Now in thee perons is there ever a tedfat decency, and uniform difference of manners oberved whereoever you find them? However each interrupt the others tory and actions.

And as for actions of perons, there are many rarely and perfectly decribed. As the mutiny and fire in a hip; caues of an uproar; The Garboyl; an armed skirmih; policy and preparation. Sometimes managing a Hore is decribed; tilting and hews. Many other lively and notable portracts there are, which I will not et down to ave you o weet a labour, as the reading of that which alone will make you eloquent and wie. Sir Philip Sidneys coure (beides reading Aritotle and Theophratus) was to imagine the thing preent, that his pen might the better decribe it.

Under this notion of Illutration may come lively decriptions, and the apt fitting a peron repreented with peech and action, both which grow into very pleaing acquaintance with the undertanding and memory of the Reader.

For peciall light in every Sentence, there are other parks of Figures. Firt, if there be any doubt or ambiguity in the words, it is better left out then ditinguihed. But if you are to anwer former peeches, that imply any doubtfulnes, you may dipere all clouds, and remove all cruples with Ditinction. As being charged you have brought very light reaons, you may anwer, If by
light you mean clear, I am glad you ee them; If by light, you mean of no weight, I am orry you do not feel them. So you may expres a man of hidden learning, Hidden as well for the obcure and mean etate of his peron, as hidden for the unuuall and not vulgar conceit of the matter. But as ambiguity is not onely in words but in matter; o both wayes it is taken away by Ditinction. Sometimes it is in ingle words, as in thee former, light and hidden. Somtimes in coherence of Sentences, by reaon of the relation of each word to other, or by reaon of the change of the pointing, which is cleared by delivery. You have many examples of this in the econd Book of Tully de Oratore, and Quintilian, where there is mention of Jocus ab ambiguo. As alo in Eramus his Apothegmes.

Ditinction of ambiguity in matters of determination of the truth of generall propoitions, is to tell wherein they are certain, wherein they are not. As, Travell in foreign Countreys, ettles a young mans humor. If it be taken in this ort, that it will inforce him to warines and ecreie, and retrain him from pouring forth his counails, it is very profitable: For he hall have few friends in whom to put confidence, and few companions with whom he might betow his idle time, or communicate his youthfull thoughts. But if you intend that, by travell, all vanities hould be cat off, it eems not o likely and admirable, becaue he hall walk through many ill examples, and great liberty. Another propoition ditinguihed. They are but frail merits that you hall betow upon young mens friendhip. 'Tis true, if you atisfie thoe deires which are like to depart with their youth; As, gaming, feating, idle porting, you are like to be cat off with thee toys, and forgotten. But if your deerts be in noble Exercies, learned Conferences, and civill frien •• y Offices, the remembrance
thereof will increae as fat as their dicretion.

So much for Ditinction; Next follows Definition, which is the hortet and truet expoition of the nature of any thing; hereof you have examples of all vertues in Aritotles Morals, of paions in his Rhetorique, both in Thomas Aquinas ecunda and ecundae, of many affections and perturbations in Tuculan's Quetions, and Cicero de Finibus, as the generall definition of vertue is this, VIRTUS EST HABITUS RATIONI CONSENTANEUS. Vertue is a quality eated in Reaon. Fear is an apprehenton of future harm. Thrift is a moderate and lawfull increae of wealth by carefull governmemt of your own etate. Complement is a performance of affected Ceremonies in words, looks, and getures. Where Definition runs into diviion of even or eight ways. Of Definition you may read Valerius his Logick. But (to be mot perfectly intructed) read the ixth book of Aritotles Top. Your definitions need be no more tied to the Rules of Logicians, then your diviions. The matter is ometimes illutrated by Periphrais; As, spur'd his hore apace; Made his purre claim hat of his hore. A man not to be contemned; Nor a man over whom contempt might make any jut chalenge. Snorting lowd; Snorting o lowd, that no man might lay the tealing of a nap to his charge. But of Pariphrais and Periphrais more everally.

Sometimes a Parentheis makes your dicoure more gracefull and intelligible: As, Tell me ingenuouly (if there be any ingenuity in you) whether, &c. That what his wit could conceive (and his wit can conceive as far as the limits of reaon tretch) was all directed to the etting forth of his friend. Till the next morning (better known to be o by the Hour-glas, then
the days clearnes) having run fortune, &c. And indeed all Parenthees are in extreams, either graces or foyles to a Speech. If they be long, they eem interruptions, and therefore at the end of them mut be a retreat to the matter, called ANTANACLASIS. As, Aure thy elfe mot wicked woman (that hat o plaguily a corrupted mind, as that thou cant not keep thy icknes to thy elf, but mut mot wickedly infect others) Aure thy elf, I ay, &c. Shall that heart (which does not only feel them, but hath all motion of his life placed in them,) Shall that heart, I ay, &c.

Diviion is a evering the whole into parts, as of time into that pat, preent, and to come, (which is rather a breathing then a Diviion) into upream or ubordinate. From their order; beats or unreaonable creatures, into thoe of the Air, Water, Earth; Love is either of Beauty, or of Vertue. From the object. Study is of Liberal or Mathematick Science. And o you may divide as many ways as things may differ, as by their beginnings, endi • gs, properties, marks, effects, times, tunes, place • , forms, perons, in whom they are, and howoever, which properly belongs to Logick; yet omething is poken thereof, in our econd way of Amplification. Out of Diviions arie three everall inforcements and manifetations of your purpoe, which (though by Rhetoritians diverly handled and tearmed) yet are they in effect grounded upon the Art of Ditribution.

The firt is Expedition, which (touching upon divers parts) detroys all, but that, on which you mean to ret; As, One of thee coures mut be taken, either you mut ditinctly oberve and practie thee Rules, or deny that ever you received Instructions, or alledge want of capacity in your elf, or want of ue of
them in your life. That they are not neceary, you cannot ay, for what more neceary in your life, then to write well? That you are uncapable, is a lander, and a contradiction to your own concience and my experience, that hath een uch fair Eayes of your endeavours. And to ay you had never any directions, were to give your two eyes the lie, and to make me believe, that I did never but dream your good. Therefore mut your labour conpire with my inventions, and o mut you unavoidably become skilfull. This is Enumeration and Inference, whereupon is that which the Logicians call Induction, as in reckoning up. It is neither that nor this, therefore this. And as one merrily aith, It is the Dogs Syllogime in a cros way, or that, or that, but I mell him not this way, nor this way, therefore he runs on his concluion the third way, without melling.

The econd of this ort is PROSOPODOSIS, that overthrows no part of the Diviion, but returns ome part to each member. In Arcadia thus, Heretofore I accued the Sea, condemned the Pyrats, and hated my evil fortune, that deprived me of thee: But now thy elf art the Sea, thy elf the Pyrat, and thy will the evil fortune. Time at one intant eeming hort and long to them; hort in the pleaingnes of uch preence, and long in tay of their deires. Your ilence mut carry with it a contruction of contempt, unkindenes or dipleaure. If you take me not for your friend, you offer unkindenes; if you deem me unworthy of an anwer, it proceeds of contempt; if your Paion defers a reply, it argues dipleaure. The firt of thee denyed all parts, ave one: This affirms and keeps all ides up. The lat is Dilemma, which propoes two ides, and overthrows both ability and will to write well: for to ay I cannot, is Childih; and I will not, is Womanih.

div.head: PERIPHRASIS & PARAPHRASIS.
div.p:
There is in the bet Writers oftentimes a vain of tile, wherein vulgar fancies are exceedingly pleaed, and know not wherewith. For they admire this mot, that there is ome excellency in it, and yet they themelves upect that it exceeds their admiration. In ome examples I would gladly dicover the reaon hereof: It cannot be, that if either the meaning of the words be obcure, and unfamiliar to a mans undertanding, that the peech o compoed, hould be o accepted: And yet it is poible that there may be ome extraordinary fancy in ordinary words, and plain meanings, how then hall we determine? It is as in many uual dihes at a table, both eyes and tate give them commendation, not for the ubtance, but for the dreing and ervice. What plainer meaning then, leep among thieves? And verily leep, life trut and thieves, are common Englih words, yet is it no common way of peaking, to ay, To trut a leeping life among thieves. In the ame ene, when they had lept a while, is ordinary. But when they had a while hearkened to the perwaion of leep, is extraordinary. Though all the words of it by themelves are mot known and f • miliar; yet the ordering and fetch of it is trange and admirable to the ignorant; We therefore call it Periphrais or Circumlocution, and it is much helped by Metaphors, as before: inclined to leep is expret by a Metaphor taken from one who moves and inclines by perwaions. But let us have one combate more with our adverary leep; for, having rien early, having triven with the uns earlines; Intead of Mopa wept ill-favouredly, Mopa digraced weeping
with her countenance. Intead of aying they that guarded Amphialus, were killed themelves; its aid, eeking to ave him, they lot the fortrees, which nature had planted them in.
