Intead of Plangus peech began to be upected; it is aid, Plangus peech began to be tranlated into the language of upicion. Thus purpoely did Sir Philip write, to keep his tile from flatnes. As being to name a Threher, he calls him one of Ceres ervants, Intead of his name was known to high and low; he aith, That no Prince could pretend highnes, nor beggar lownes, to bar him from the ound thereof. And this is by going a CONCRETO AD ABSTRACTUM, and divers other ways.

If a hort ordinary ene be oddely expret by more words, it is Pariphrais; but if by as many other, it is Paraphrais: as, manifet Oathes, plentiful perjury. To make a great hew of himelf. To make a muter of himelf in the Iland: for kill any marryed man; make his word cured by any widow, which is by conequence, eeking by curteie, to undo him. Making curteie the outide of michief, by Similitude or Metaphor: o then the coure is, intead of any ordinary words importing a trivial matter, to take the abtracts, or ome conequence, imilitude, note, property or effect, and thereby expres it. Thee two figures erve for Illutration.

It is ometimes requiite for gaining life and lutre in your dicoure, to repreent ome unexpected trangenes, beides the tenor of your Theame or Story: and, as it were, to act your meaning; which is done either by faigning the preence or the dicoure of ome uch perons, as either are not at all: or if they be, yet peak not but by your imagination. The firt is by Apotrophe or Proopopeia.

APOSTROPHE, is a turning of your peech to ome new peron, as to the people or witnees, when it was before to the • udges or Defendant: as, Herein you witnees are to conult with your own conciences, and to enter into a true examination of your own memory. Did you mark • is looks? Did you note his peeches? Did you truly conceive the particular proceedings of the Action? To the people thus, Now let me intreat any man here preent, that thinks himelf not exempted from misfortunes, and priviledged from all mischiefs, to imagine himelf in my cae, and to undertake for my ake ome few thoughts of my Ditres. Sometimes the occaion is taken from ome quality or other thing, whereto your elf gives hew of life; as, Hope tell me, what hat thou to hope for? Love, be ahamed to be called Love. But to animate, and make dead men peak is PROSOPOPAEIA; as, If your Ancetors were now alive, and aw you defacing o goodly a Monument by them erected, would they not ay thus, &c. And as Sir Philip Sidney gives ene and peech to the Needle and Silk in Pamela's hands, as learning, as a Lily: as death it elf is faigned to live, and make a peech.

Another way of clearing and reviving your dicoure, is by deliberating, by entring into communication, by preventing and anwering Objections. In deliberating ometimes you are amazed; as, Whom hall I blame? what hall I pretend? hall I make learning hateful to you by my reprehenions? hall I make my ilence acceary to your idlenes? div.p:
INcontancy is properly a levity and an irreolution of mind, which hewes it elf in his manners,
actions and words, who is touched with it. To ay truth, this paion is a Divell that inhabits in a land of Quickilver, where Earthquakes are al • ot perpetuall, windes blow on each ide, and blowing, make many weather-cocks turn to & fro and every moment change poture. In this place a • admirable creature is to be een, who is not what he is, and is that he is not, o many faces and figures he hath: She likewie is till upon transformations, and eems to do nothing at all, but to make and unmake herelf. One while he is great, another while little; one while gros, another while l • nder; one while affable, anoth • r while harh; one while erious, another while gameome, but ever lippery; and if you lay hold of her, you catch nothing. She goes forth of her lodging to appear in publique, as if he came into a Theater, cloathed one while in changeable Taffata, another while with different pieces, et together out of a ingular fantatick addlenes of wit. div.head: Hope.
div.p: HOpe is the gate of a great Palace replenihed with riches. It is in my opinion the place which Tertullian termes, The Porteres of Nature. It is the preumpt •• us mans Divell, which leads him a while in a mo • th way, & then makes him break his neck o • the udden. Hope is to man as a bladder to a learning wimmer, &c. Feltham
—The ight wherof made Hope (the Harbinger of happines) to breath in her this pleaing c • mfort.

div.head: Jealouie.
div.p: IEalouie is a dieae of the mind, proceeding from a fear which a man hath, that that thing is communicated to another, which he would not have common, but privat to himelf: it is alo bred of that love which will not uffer a partner in the thing beloved.

div.p: INgratitude chalenges revenge by Cutome, and is a vice mot hatefull before God and Man.

div.p: JOy triumpht in his eys and comfort lodg'd in his heart, and in this haven of happines he would have wimmed till, but that—

div.head: Letters.
div.p: LEtters are the very thoughts of the heart, but once removed, where all the capes of nature or breeding are mot like to harbor. Rey. of Cab.

div.head: I • tructions for writing and addresing LETTERS,
div.p: IN writing of Letters there may be four things regarded, the Invention; the Fahion, or inditing (as we call it); the Hand-writing, and the Orthography; though the two firt are mot coniderable.

Invention arieth from your buines, whereof there can be no Rules of more c • rtainty, or precepts of better direction given, then conjecture may lay down of the everall occaions of all mens particular lives and vocations. But ometimes men make buines of kindnes; As, I could not atisfie my elf, till I had dicharged my remembrance, and charged my Letters with commendations to you. My buines is no other but to tetifie my love to you, and to put you in mind of my willingnes to do you any ervice: Or, have you leaure to decend to the remembrance of that aurance you have long had in me; and upon your next opportunity to make me happy with any imployment, you hall aign me, &c. or uch like words, which go a begging for ome meaning, and labour to be delivered of the great Burden, Nothing.

When you have invented, if your buines be matter, and not bare form, not meer ceremony, but of ome concern, Then you are to proceed to the ordering it, and digeting the parts, which is ought out of two circumtances: One is the undertanding of the reaons to whom you write; the other is the coherence of the matter; for mens capacity and delight, you are to weigh what will be apprehended firt with greatet attention and pleaure, what next regarded & longed for epecially, and what lat will leave mot atisfaction, & as it were the weetet relih & memorial of all that is pat in his undertanding to whom you write.

For the conequence of entences, you mut ee that every claue do as it were give the cue to the other and eem to be bepoken ere it come, order & coherence in writing being that fire of Prom •
theus, without which all our works would appear inanimate.

Now for Fahion, it conits in four qualities of your Style. The firt is Brevity; For Letters mut not be Treaties or d • coures, except it be amongt learned men, and even amongt them there is a kind of thrift and aving of words. You are therefore to examine the clearet paages of your undertanding, and through them to convey the weetet and mot ignificant Englih words you can devie, that you may the eaier teach them the readiet way to another mans fancy, and to pen it fully, moothly, and ditinctly; o as the Reader may not think a econd view cat away upon your Letters. In eff • ct, th • goodnes of words is, as the foundation of all Eloquence; and he aid well, who compared them to garments, that were invented for neceity, yet did alo erve for ornament.

But though repect be a part after this, yet mut
I here remember it. If you write to a peron, with whoe condition and humor you are well acquainted, you may be the bolder to et a • ask to his brain. If to your uperior, you are bound to meaure in him three further points; Firt, your Interest in him; econdly, his capacity of your Letters; thirdly, his leaure to perue them. For your interet, or favour with him, you are to be the horter or longer, more familiar or ubmis, as he will afford you time. For his Capacity, you are to be quainter, or fuller of thoe reaches or glances of wit or learning, according to his comprehenion; For his leaure, you are commanded to the greater brevity, as his place is of greater dicharges and cares. With your betters, you are not to put Riddles of wit, by being too niggardly of your words, nor to caue the trouble of making Breviats, by writing too copiouly, or watingly.

Brevity is attain'd upon the matter, by avoiding idle complements, prefaces, protetations, long Parenthees, upplications, wanton circuits of Figures, and digreions, by compoition, omitting conjunctions, Not onely but alo, the one and the other, whereby it comes to pae, &c. and uch like particles, that have no great buines in a erious Letter; By breaking off entences; as oftentimes a hort journey is made long by many baits. But as Quintilian aith, There is a briefnes of the parts ometimes, that makes the whole long; As, I came to the stairs, I took a pair of Oares, they lanched out, rowed apace, I landed at Wetminter, I paid my Fare, went to the Parliament Houe, asked for a Member, I was admitted. All this is, but I went to Wetminter, and pake with my friend.

Under this Notion omewhat may be aid
of Periods, which ought not to bee too long, nor yet too hort, QO MAGIS VIRTS, EO MAGIS MEDIETAS. All vertue conits in a certain Geometricall mediocrity, equally ditant from exces and default. Some Writers have precribed a Period not to exceed that length which a man may well pronounce in a breath. There ought likewie to be a peciall regard had to the cadence of the words, that the whole contexture of the Period may yeeld a certain kind of harmony to the ear; for Longinus ays, The true ounds and tones of Periods may be compared to a great Feat made up of many dihes,

The next property of Epitolary Style, is, Perpicuity, which is not eldom endangered by the former quality. Brevity oftentimes by affectation of ome wit, or otentation of ome hidden termes of Art, is ill angled for; few words darken peech, and o do too many; as well too much light hurts the eyes, as too little; and a long Bill of Chancery confounds the undertanding as much as the hortet note. Therefore let not your letter be pen'd like an Englih Statute, and be ure to avoid fungous words, and empty inflations; which may bet be done by conidering your buines, and ditinctly undertanding your elf; and this will be much furthered by examining your thoughts, and expoing them as well to the light and judgment of your own outward enes, as to the cenure of other mens ears. 'Tis for want of this conideration that many good Scholers peak but faltringly, like a rich man that for want of particular note and difference, can bring you no ware readily out of his hop. By this means talkative hallow men ometimes content the hearers more then the wie. But this may find a peedier redres in writing, where
all comes under the lat examination of the Eyes. Firt, mind it well, then pen it, then examine it, then amend it, and you may be in the better hope of writing accurately.

Under this vertue may come Plainnes, which is, not to be too curious in the order; as to anwer a Letter, as if you were to anwer Interrogatories, To the firt, firt, to the econd, econdly; But in the method, to ue as Ladies do in their attire, a diligent kind of negligence; NON ENIM ELOQENTIAM EX ARTIFICIO, SED ARTIFICIM EX ELOQENTIA NATM, ays Cicero. And Longinus hath this excellent obervation, That Art does then appear perfect, when he can carce be ditinguihed from Nature her elf. And though with ome men you are not to jet, or practie capricio's of wit; yet the delivery of the mot weighty and important matter, may be carried with uch an eaie grace, as it may tickle the fancy of the Reader, and yeeld a recreation to the Writer, as Plato oberves, lib. 6. de Legib.

There mut be variety, but not exces of terms, as if you are to name tore, ometimes you may call it choyce, ometimes plenty, ometimes copie, or variety, But ever o, as the word that comes in. lieu, have no uch difference of meaning, as to put the ene in hazard to be mitaken.

You are not to cat a ring for the perfumed moding terms of the time; as to acquiece, to epoue an interet, to cajole, to incommode, to have a pique againt one, &c. but ue them properly in their places, as others; matter & ubtance being preferra • le before words or form: For as a modern French Author ays, the mot excellent words without olidity
of matter, are no more coniderable, then the burt of a Cannon without Ball, which makes a great noye, but does no execution. Beides, a vain curioity of words hath o much candalized ome Philoophers, that Seneca (in one of his Epitles) ays, Had it been poible to make himelf undertood by ignes, he would rather erve himelf of them, then of dicoure, to the end he might the • etter avoid all manner of affectation. Whereunto may pertinently be ubjoyned thoe excellent lines of Mr. Hobbs (in his anwer to Sir Will. Davenants Preface) in thee words: As the ene we have of bodies, conits in-change and varity of impreion; o alo does the ene of language in variety and changeable ue of words: I mean not in the affectation of words newly brought home from travell, but in the new (and withall ignificant) tranlation to our purpoes, of thoe that be already received, and in far-fetch'd (but withall apt, intructive and comely) imilitudes.

There follows Life, which is the trength and inews (as it were) of your tyle, by pretty ayings, imilitudes and conceits, alluions, ome known hitory or other Common-place, uch as are in the econd book of Tully, de Oratore. And (if we may credit Hermogenes) a moderate interlacing of vere among proe, is not without its gentilee.

But too great a mixture of other languages in your tyle, ome (and thoe of the more learned) have compared to a party coloured coat, made up of everall pieces of tuff; others to Anacr • ons Swan, which had neither blood, fleh, nor bone.

The fourth is Respect, to dicern what befits your elf, him to whom you write, and the matter you treat of, which is a quality fit to conclude the ret, becaue it does include the ret; and that mut proceed from ripenes of judgment, which (as an
Author truly ays) is gotten by four ways, by the gift of God, by Nature, diligence, and converation; erve the firt well, and the ret will erve you.

In the cloe of your letter you mut by all means endeavour to come off handomly, by avoyding thoe trite and over-worn concluions, Thus I ret, So I remain, Thus I take my leave, & the like; and by taking rie from the next precedent matter of your letter, make your ubcription appendent thereto.

For the Hand-writing, if you attain not to perfection, it ought at leat to be legible, and the matter fairly written, and truly pointed, with Comma (,) Colon (:) Semicolon (;) Period (.) Parenthees (Interrogation (?) and Admiration (!) points, as the matter requires.

The lat is the Orthography, or true writing of words, which (though not much valued by ome, yet) I hold a quality o incident to a good Penman, that he cannot be aid to be perfect in that faculty, without it; nor do I beleeve that one of ten, even among Scholars, are well skild therein. And of this Orthography, as it were too long to be here treated of, o may I haply give you hereafter ome obervations thereupon.

div.p: MY teeming hopes have been fed even with an aurance, that London hould e're this have been made happy with your preence, ele I had not thus long hazarded the los of your good opinion by my ilence; ince I confee to owe a debt to your goodnes, which all the repect and ervice my poore abilities are able to perform, can never throughly atisfie. I beg, at preent, but a continuance of your favours towards me; and (becaue I know you jut) hall onely expect them hereafter according to the meaure of my ervices, which I have faithfully devoted to your bet el, in quality of,

closer.signed: Your vertues humble honourer, T. B.

div.head: VI. A Letter from a Gentleman banihed the Lines of Communication, to a Lady in London.
div.p: IF I could decline the thought of a neceity of being here, and believe this Banihment to be a voluntary retirement, I hould account my elf extreamly happy; for here we freely enjoy thoe felicities o much ought for in London, the freh air, and inging of the Nightingale; yet I mut confee I begin to be atiated with thee olitary pleaures, not o uitable with my dipoition, as the converation of my friends; and could willingly exchange the company of Birds and Beats, for the ociety of men. But, pardon me (Madam) it was not my intention to trouble you with what I do or uffer, or to wih you where I would not be my elf; but to beeech you to retain a memory of me, till I am retor'd to the honour of kiing your hands, a happines daily deired by

div.head: VII. A econd Letter of alutation, upon the micarriage of a former.
VIII. An Anwer to a Letter of kindnes.
div.p: THe great meaure of content I received at your being here, and ince that, the favour to be the unworthy object of your remembrance, makes me even proud of my own happines. The truth is, I wih no other heaven upon earth, then always to enjoy your preence, that the influence of your many vertues may create in me ome kind of goodnes. But ince there mut needs be a eparation, excue it I beeech you if in this homely manner, I preent you with the ervice and bet affection of him that is,

closer.signed: Mot happy in your acknowledgment, T B.

div.head: IX. A paionate letter of affection.
div.p: SInce that very hour, wherein Fortune made me happy in your knowledge, next under God I neither have love, care, hope, nor contentment, but for you: The day yeelds up all my thoughts, as a tribute to your memory, and the night (which was made to arret the agitations of Spirit) never removes the remembrance of you from my heart; over which, as you have already gain'd an abolute dominion, o hall it yeeld you a contant acrifice of an affection which hall be permanent, as the Being of

closer.signed: Your mot devoted ervant, T. B.

div.head: X. A Letter from a Commander in war to his Mitres.
div.p:
THough I have lately been brought even to the confines of Deaths Kingdom, yet I reteine o much trength, as to tell you I am alive; and mut crawe leave to renue that • protetation, which I have heretofore o often made, not to be willing to live but for your ervice. The cars of war in ome ort reemble the wounds of love, ince thoe which I received, have not at all diminihed the deire I had to erve my Religion, and thee, which you gave me, have increas'd that paion to honor you which reignes within my oul. My hand has not trength eno • gh to write more, and its weaknes may erve as a proof of my affection,
which hall be always greater then my power, as the effects of my obedience hall ever be lee, then my devotion to erve you, all days of my life, in quality of

closer.signed: The dearet lover of your bet elfe, T. B.

div.head: XI. A Conolatory Letter.
div.p:
I Have received your gracious lines, of which I make a Jewel; becaue both in themelves good, as alo becaue I take them not to be common. For thee are the conditions, that upon mot things et a value; But could thoe be wanting, yet would they not want a high rate, had they no other vertue, then the coming from you; If their kindnes to me had bin accompanied with the characters of your own more wihed Fortunes, they had by far, been more contentfull: whereas now, as they tell me, I have a friend, they at the ame view add, he's far les happy then I could wih her; Thus the ame yllables make the ame thoughts at once, both haples and fortunate. But, Madam, as the news generall, and your particular, hare both in malignity, becaue both bad; o I hope yours at leat is at the wort, and by equele upon amendment; and hopes of better is always a fair point of good fortune, which to make more ure, you to your elf will not (I hope) be wanting. There was a Phyloopher aid, that each one is the framer of his own Fate; and I am partly of his Sect, at leat o farre as I believe no fate o bad, but 'tis in the power of the ufferer to make it (if not
good) better. And o Madam (I hope) will both your widom and vertue endeavour; and this by olid grounds and ways, without which the ret will be labour in vain. The task you have et me to this end (to wit) my prayers, I both daily have, do, & wil perform; and if a partner in misfortunes might leen the burthen, as ome have thought, I I cannot be without my part in yours. Nor, wer't in my power, hould your Ladihip be a moment without better comforts. But I leave this ad train till fitter opportunity, and ret,

div.head: XII. A paionate Letter of affection.
div.p:
THe long continuance of all things (my infinite love to you excepted) does by little and litle decay them; but 'tis my pride, that each grey hair time adds to the affection I bear you (which again I pronounce infinite) brings an inclination to a econd infinity, and remains the onely excuable dotage now extant, turning my preent olitary life to one of much buines; for always to think of you I eteem my buines, my faith, my every thing. Your contancy can never find out a greater then mine; for 'tis a vat one, and hall outlat all things about it; Therefore look that yours
be as true marble, as you will otherwie anwer the utter undoing of

closer.signed: Your truly, truly, truly, contant ervant.

div.head: XII. To a Landlord in behalf of his Tenants.
div.p: TO move you to jutice were in ome ort to conclude you guilty of injutice, and to requet your pitie in hehalf of your poor and long oppreed Tenants, were to proclaim you hard-hearted againt them; but experience tells me you are free from both, and your own works pronounce your worth. Onely thus much I am bold to beg of you, that the fale informations of A.B.C.D. and others of broken credits, as well as Etates, may not take place againt thee bearers, men of honor and good fortunes, and uch as I dare preume will inform you of nothing but truth. In confidence whereof I aume the liberty to ububcribe my elfe,

div.head: XIV. A econd Letter, upon a late acquaintance.
div.p:
AFter one Letter (long ince ent) and often inquiries, I have, at lat, had the happines to
hear your afety and health. The Relator had an accidentall view of you, and I a reall comfort. I was once made fortunate by opportunity to enjoy your obliging converation, and engag'd by your noble endearments, but this lot, almot as oon as gain'd; o vanihing the chiefe enjoyances of this fickle life, o unlating thoe contents we eteem mot ingenious and innocent. Sir, I have many ties to be yours, and not fewer misfortunes, that I may not be o as much as I would. But this is a world of croes, uch as, though it hath pull'd many down, yet hath it et others up in the tead. And this mut be o, ince without a cros we cannot arrive our Crown. However, neither ditance of place, nor intervall of time can change thoe repects to your noble elf, that took both root and date from our firt enterview. Affection grounded on vertue, mut parallell it in content, or be injurious. Your true worth engaged me in ever-honoring eteems, and thee I mut be unworthy if I recall. Nor are our immortall ouls o menurated to place, but they can meet; though our duller clay be confin'd to the accident of commenuration; what they cannot perform by preence, by operation they can; remain where they live, and be where they love; in the circumference be di-joyned, yet united in the center of hearts, which is their life and Being; and this is God. Here (Sir) was our firt union, and here, I hope, nothing hall eparate: yea each flying moment of time drawes to a more embooming neernes. Sir, when we parted you enjoyned me to continue you in my bet thoughts, This not to remember, I account to forget my elf. That I am not banihed your memory,
one word from your pen, would not onely cherih and confirm, but honor and oblige,

closer.signed: Your mot devoted and humble ervant, D.W.

div.head: XV. A Letter to excue ilence, &c.
div.p:
VVHat to you I know not, but to me it eems long, ince my pen preented my repects. 'Tis true, I wrote lat, but this wil not excue. Gratitude makes my addrees due; when you alute, your alutes are pure favours: till oblige, never incurre obligation. If then I have been too remis, I flie to the Ayle of your pardon; and to render me more capable of it, give me leave to add this qualif • cation: That not neglect, but fear to be troubleome, caued the intervall. Et modus in rebus — I would oberve duty, I hate to be uneaonable: He that can light on the Mean, attains the accomplihment of Office; he that mies, may mean well, but is guilty of ome defection towards an extream. But as that morall Decorum is the beauty of humane life; o a precie nicenes with friends, hath too much of cruple. Seemlines hould not be trangret, yet Friendhip is not tern in her Laws. I may be bold with my elf, and next with my friend. Whom endearment makes mutuall, love intitles to a latitude of honet action. o Sir, that I bear the tile of your Friend, is the greatet adjunct the world can make me happy in; I deire no more plendor of honor,
no relation to me is o pretious. My requet is, it may continue; my endeavour hall be to deerve the continuance; not that I preume I can deerve it, but rather, that I hope, not by a voluntary guilt, to forfeit what you freely conferre. Nor wil you eaily (your goodnes is too contant) reject, whom you have (with o much condecence) adopted. My reolve is unchangeable, and that is, to be

closer.signed: Ever and mot intirely your devoted ervant, D.W.

div.head: XVI. To a Mother.
div.p: THis hort time of abence make me enible of that great good which Nature gave me, when he ordain'd you to be the Parent & me the child; for now I feel my elf deprived of thoe joyes, which your preence was wont to afford me; now I want thoe lovefull apects, wherewith your indulgent eye was wont to olace me. In a word, I want all things, which an affectionate mother did ever betow upon an undeerving, yet dutifull child, for uch is

div.head: XVII. A Letter to beg acquaintance.
div.p: YOu may wonder at this boldnes: but your worth animates it, and the ame, I hope, will pardon what it caues. I have often heard of you, and once I aw you; and by the converation of a few words, I perceiv'd plentifull evidence, that what I have heard of your merits, was anwered in the truth. This your humility may reply was too hort a time for experience. I grant it: but not to confirm what both the Good and Wie by report had made credible: the enes hould not be deceived in their proper objects; and Hearing is a ene as wel as Seeing: and (if it follow the right Rules) perhaps as little erring; chiefly if a rationall hearing, to which I have om title by eence. Report the ubject; that you are deerving, the reported; this aver'd by wie men and good men, yea by all men that know you; which I mut either believe or be irrationall. Sir, the truth is, I am o fully perwaded of this verity, that I am truly ambitious of your more acquaintance; and that this may be by pen, till more joyn'd aboads afford a preentiall intercoure. If your thoughts anwer, no greater obligation can be laid upon

div.head: XVIII. In anwer to a Letter of Complement.
div.p: THat I live (though abent) thus freh in your memory, I count my glory, and that you write to me, my happines; which favours, that I may eem in ome meaure to deerve, I addres thee, not as atisfactory Acquittances (for uch my weak merit, does not aim at) but as repective acknowledgements, which your greater goodnes commands from me. I have now throughly both een and felt the Bath, and as I find my elf nothing ameliorated in complexion of face, or temperature of body; o is the dipoition of my mind to erve you nothing leened, but does adequately increae, with the obligations of

div.head: XIX. A facetious letter upon ending a Chritmas Pye to a Friend.
div.p:
I Salute you with a poor token, a patry Bak'd-meat, as a recognition of my gratitude for your noble entertainments; and not entertainments only, but even harbour in a puh of neceity, which I contrue to have multiplied the curteie to many degrees of height. Thee to requite I confes my elf unable, and to forget as unwilling. The mean
of both I undertake, that is to greet you with my gratefull and remembring repects: which if you pleae to entertain in my ene, it hall be interpreted a new added favour, and peak me thankful. Gratefull minds can acknowledge what they cannot retribute, and this is both my fortune and meaning. Sir, that I may be ome imperfect Index, or like the Wetminter Tomb-hewer, tell who or what lyes here: You have or hall find in the center, a Neats Tongue, empanched by a Gooe; next both tongue and Gooe, like the Ile of Candia, wallowed up by the Turk; Round thee, ome few other Volatils, as lookers on, and though not main Partizans, yet not unimbroyl'd in the danger, for their curioity. At lat comes fierce Generall Cook, and fortifies all (as he hopes) with a trong line of Circumvallation, and having perfected his works, ends the beieged captive to your bet appetite, whereto they are left for triumph and conquet. Sir, now were it not for fear of making this our Pot-pate over tedious, and coming too neer the heels of time, I could o compare thee Animals, or their corps, that there might rie upon their conditions both Emblems and Morals. But this acetenes I will leave to your elf and good company, to recreate and abetter your digetion with. What I chiefly deire to hear in this point, is, that you have been merry in parting the fray, friendly accepted what was cordially meant: That you have vanquihed the cruell Turk, the peevih Gooe, the betrayi • g Tongue, the wild Pouline, the long-nos'd Woodcocks; yea that you have raz • d the very proud outworks to the ground. This done, I pray, you may conquer your wore enemies, and number me in the Alb • of

div.head: XX. A Letter to excue ilence, and acknowledge pat favours.
div.p: I Have long done you the ervice, not to trouble you with my lines, but durt no longer purue this method, let it might degenerate into the emblance of neglect. It ver • ue (for her better practice) be enthron'd twixt two extreams, writing (as an act of vertue) mut alo keep due ditance with them; neither lean to importune frequency without leave, nor be benumb'd by the Lethargy of Omiion. And you, whoe favours have always engaged me yours, will believe my aimes have no other end, then to be o, as well in forbearances as actions; provided I fail not as your votary; a crime I hould hate my elf to think I could be wicked enough to commit; and am ure I never yet was. Sir, you have, I know, received my former Letter, and dained the civility of receiving from it my humble gratitudes, for the liberalities it acknowledged. This wil not o far encroach upon the Office of my better expreions, as to repent that duty, but mut again and again pronounce me

div.head: XXI. A Letter of thanks, &c.
div.p:
I Have received your friendly Letter, and (by Proxie) your bounty: I am obliged by both, yet
am by you debar'd, by pen, to anwer either. You fetter me in the limits of ten lines, and thee too mut be ilent of your elf, the bet ubject; I could oberve your number, and yet be tedious, did I write hort hand, or would I imitate the Lawyers length of a Chancery Bill. But I will not force a double ene on your incerity; What you will not have in paper, hall warm my br • at, thoe gratefull thoughts, and unfeigned devotions, that vow and maintain me

closer.signed: Your ever mot affectionate ervant, D.W.

div.head: XXII. To a Lady upon her weaving hair-bracelets.
div.p: LAt night when I found you in a pretty harmles employment, weaving hair-bracelets, you commanded me to make you ome Poeies for that purpoe, which I told you was a work fitter for Poets and men of wit, then for me, whoe Cabinet enhrineth no uch Treaure; yet (Madam) that you may ee what a upremacy of power you have over all my faculties, I end you thee incloed; if any of which prove worth your ue, the compoure mut be acribed to the vertue of your commands, rather then to any skill of mine, which as I diclaim to have, out of a jut ene of my own imperfections; o mut I always ubcribe my elfe (out of a like ene of your worth)

closer.signed: Your mot devoted ervant, T. B.
