div.head: XXIII. A Letter complaining of Abence.
div.p:
IF I could find out words to expres the language of my heart, I hould then be able to demontrate how little I enjoy my elf, whilt I am abent from you, in whom all my joyes and all my felicities are o wealthily um'd up; that as I live by none but you; o, were it as much in my power as deires, I hould never be abent from you; But ince Fate hath thus decreed a eparation, I beeech you let
nothing make you forget him, who always remembers you, in quality of

div.head: XXIV. In anwer to one that congratulated an arrivall in the Countrey.
div.p: THat you congratulated our well-coming to G. was o neceary for us, and o great a mark of goodnes in you, that I believe without your good wihes, we had taken up our quarters on Saturday night in the Forret, where we were benighted (a ad thing to think on) and lot our way; But being (as I ay) arrived here, by the help of God, and your good wihes, I find little ubject for envy in our enjoyments, not a Deer being left in the Park, nor a Kid in eaon, (unles a woodden one) nor a Walk dry enough for a Spanih-leather hooe; and I am ure you will not envy us a little freh air, ince we have paid o dear for it, by the fatigues of a long journey. Trut me (Sir) thee things (however you value them) bend my thoughts towards London, and the rather, in repect of your dear elf, to whom I am (by manifold obligations)

closer.signed: An affectionate humble ervant, T. B.

div.head: XXV. pon the late Commotions.
div.p:
HAd not Pithagoras excepted our Terretriall Orbe, when hee aerted the Orbes harmonious; this Age had clearly confuted him. For how muicall oever thoe higher are; this I am ure ounds nothing but harh Dicords: and o lowd; that wee cannot but hear them; o unpleaant, that the dinne dicompoes quiet minds. The way to eae our elves is hard, yet not impoible: but what is it? 'tis this, To elevate our abode: To Compoe our own interiour. He that enjoyes in time Peace, is not open to extern broiles: they may beat the out ide, but cannot enter; batter the walls of fleh and bloud, but the Citadell of reaon is afe; and if reaon way, wee fly up to manions inditurbd. We are all Citizens of the lower World, I grant, mut wih 'tis good; may deplore it's evills; Yet our own private welfare, ought to be to us mot precious. This were a Paradox with Polititians (if not well gloed) and o I allow it (each part was made for the whole.) But our Placite till tands: and tands in this: each mortall is nearet to himelf. My own preervation, leens not my contribution to the Publicke mut I bee, or I cannot be able? I mut be able, or I cannot aid it. Of Aides, there is more then one ort. All were not fram'd for the ame function, or influence. The Martiall blade, and bullet has it's office; o policy military; thee we leave to the ons of Mars. Yet we have our duty too, and this is piety. Piety firt calmes it's own lares; then becomes intrumentall to others
reconcilement. When heaven ees mee at peace within, I am approved, fit to pacify. To complain of exterior commotions, and my elf to be torn by the diorder of my own Paions, is an improper addres, a mediation ineffectuall. It was well dream't by Scipio, when he aid; as the intelligences guided (by a regular Order) the upper Spheres; o ought our intellectuall powers govern our own little World. Where the uperiour portion of the oul obeys the divine Lawes, and the part irrationall acquieces to the mind; (in the mind (and all man) reounds a harmony far urpaing Pithagorean accents. Ah! (my friend) were mentall and private tumults appeas'd, the civill would ceae, and whilt thee (with you and I) are etled, the civill cannot annoy us. A compo'd oul mieries may try, cannot diorder. Whilt others, then fight for earth, and purple it with native bloud; let us apire higher enterpries: pray for their peace, ecure our own. Let us fix our thoughts where ambition reaches not, where War embroiles not, where tranquillity eternally triumphes. Thus hall we offer our elves a piacular acrifice before the high Altar of God, in our own condition acceptable, in alien behoof not depied. The inceant vowes, of

div.head: XXVI. ANSWER.
div.p: YOu have given us, (who are indeed Terretriall Comopolites) mot excellent precriptions, for the compoure and regiment of the inward man in thee times of fluctuation, whereby thoe that are at War within themelves, may know how to eek, and where to find a lating peace, a peace with truth and endles repoe, and thoe that are at peace may learne how to ettle the oules Militia in an unconquerable poture of defence againt the Common enemy; In a word there's a volume of rich Apothegmes abridg'd into the compendium of your letter; heavens make my breat a fit repoitory for uch treaure. But in concluion you evidence the vertue of elf-abnegation to be one part of the Cargazon of your hip; For you till work with the old Perpectives, by erving your elf of a diminihing Glae, when you mention your own perfections, and of one, that multiplies, when you make the mole hills of your friends qualities (if any were) to eem mountains. Alas! what is my plain ong, if compared with your heavenly decant; Majores majora canunt- It mut content mee to contemplate you in a higher Orbe, whilt I ly mudling here below, even

closer.signed: The humblet of your ervants, T. B.

div.head: XXVII. To a Lady, upon her leaving the City.
div.p: EVer ince you left London, all joyes and good fortune have left us, the heavens have not ceaed to hed continual It was a time of great rain. teares for your abence, and Mars has frownd upon all our undertakings, nor can we hope to receive good news or enjoy fair weather, till the rayes and vertue of your preence returne hither, to uncloud the watry element and uncharm the fortune of War. Whilt in this adnes, I was tudying what might render my lines worthy your acceptance, the encloed arrives with the much wih'd for news of — And if this prove in any meaure an Antidote to prevent the contagion of adder thoughts, which thee times are apt to adminiter, I hall enjoy the height of my ambition, which holds no title in competition with that of

div.head: XXVIII. To excue the not taking leave, and to acknowledge received favours.
div.p:
BEfore I left London I did endeavour to have given my peronall attendance upon your noble elf, with an addres of thankfulnes for
your generous favours, and free entertainments; But this devoir (by your abenting occaions) being frutrate; I am forced upon pen-upply. Wherein yet the mot I can expres to the purpoe, is ingeniouly to avow, I owe more to your bounties than I can expree; more expreions to your high Worths, then I can make legible. Which defect of Language (I humbly yet conceive) you of all (Sir,) have mot reaon to indulge; ince your great merits of mee, and your own elf-noblenes, has mot put it to ilence. Be then above my feeble Oratory, as your endearments trancend my deerts; 'tis praie enough, as you aim not at empty Epithets, o your reall perfections are abundant and natively clear to be their own encomiums. I with admiring gratitude will remember what I cannot utter. Yet (Sir) take this unfeigned image of my thoughts; that from the firt houre I received the honour of your acquaintance, I have ingularly honour'd your elf; and ince you have bin pleaed to rank mee in the albe of your ervants, and priviledge mee not onely with your friendly familiarities, but alo ignall favours, I confee my elf bound for requitall of all, as to yeeld to none in my repect, o to be ever (as I profee I am obliged)

div.head: XXIX. A Ladies Anwer to her ervants firt letter.
div.p: THat upon o mall acquaintance, you hould make mee uch friendly and paionate expreions, I cannot but take as a civility, being apt to make the bet contruction of every ones actions; yet (Sir) that o many moneths hould pae in ilence, ince I aw you, is enough to make me believe your letter meerly complementall; For thee times afford many of your ex, whoe pens or tongues can peak one language, and their hearts another When I hall find caue to believe your profeions real, I hall et a greater value upon your repect: Mean time civility invites mee to ubcribe my elf

div.head: XXX. A Complementall Addree from one Lady to another.
div.p:
I Have not o much vanity to think to make a return, worthy the honour I have recieved, nor do I bear o little jutice to my own gratitude, as not to witnes my reentment, though great, yet in huge diproportion to your merit, whoe vertues and goodnes I hold in equall value with thoe of
demi-Gods: I receive the new aurances of your Ladyhips favour, as a bleing ent mee from heaven, which bids me cherih it and live, ince I can relih no felicity without it. Indeed (Madam) I know not what Sacrifice to offer you for uch a bounty; All hearts are made tributary to your Commands; yet none with o much obligation, as that of

div.head: XXXI. The Anwer.
div.p: YOu may ay of mee, as a Cavalier once aid of the late Synod, that they had ate long and at length hatch'd a Monter (meaning the Directory:) So have I bin long in anwering yours, & at length my dull Genius produces this ill-hapd letter: Madam, if the faculty of my pen were correpondent to the devotion of my heart, I could ay much, when as now I mut be ilent; Yet not ilent neither; For every cat of my eye upon your lines begets a wonder & wonder makes mee break ilence; I have alwayes had your weet peron and vertues in a reverentiall eteem, and now the charmes of your pen have hurld mee into new admirations; yet not o, as to forget the old, nor at any time to be leet he •

closer.signed: The mot humble of your Devotes, A.T.

div.head: XXXII. A letter from the Author of a book to the approver, Sir, N. B.
div.p:
THis hand which hath tood o long before your Barr, comes now to accue it elf of a fault by which the Judge mut needs have uffered much from the offender, ince the oulnee of the Copy, is like to have tryed your patience, more then the worth of the caue can hope to have recompencd your paines; Wherefore thee lines come before you to offer atisfaction at leat to your civility, if they fail of giving it to your judgment, and the coure of my life qualifies me better for civill dicharges, then for litterate atisfactions; You hall then Sir, receive by this a return of much ene of your fair and obliging carriage towards mee in the examination of my papers; wherein I mut deire you to conider the whole deigne, which aimes olely at morall regulations, and does rather decline then accept any inducements to controveriall doctrines; if there bee any point o incident to the ubjects, as my opinion mut needs appeare in ome dark light, this may well bee connived at by o ingenious a Judge, as your elf, who cannot expect I hould diemble my Principles, though in dicretion I was forbid to declaime upon them; So that I conceive your abilities, will make a due difference, between what may critically be ifted out, and what does litterally profee it elf; and of this lat ort, I preume you will find nothing in the whole work, that has an open face of contention or offence; Wherefore upon your animad verions,
I have changed the looks of uch places, as had any apparant features of enmity, and have offered you uch atisfaction upon the other points, I have not altered, as I hope your candor and dipaionate temper may admit; Upon the opinion whereof, I hall conclude, that if you have found, in thee my meditations, more matter promiing good influencies upon the affections of our Country, then projecting any dangerous infuions, you will allow them your contribution to that effect I have ingly propoed in them; In order whereunto my prayers hall intend the uppliment of my pens deficiency; which the lee worthy it is of this expoure to the World, the more mut it owe your patience and civility for your favour to

div.head: XXXIII. pon the New-year.
div.p:
MY preent Theme is, to give you the cerimonies (in real wihes) of a happy New-year. Nor hall I doubt the effect, ince I cannot your Piety or Prudence. No revolution of time can be inaupicious, where thee fair pair of twin-virtues are fixt, and in action. Time tells our hours, produces change, but our happines, or infortunes onely from our elves. 'Tis vain then to accue deaf fate, when we are our own detiny, or at leat it in our arbitrement. Prudence, (the eye of our
life) foreees, dipoes our affaires; Piety, our elves. That dicharges our devoirs, This guides all events (properous or advere) to our eternal (if it cannot temporall) felicity. Hence we have a method either to prevent miery, or of turning it into better luck, by being unhappy. Cros chances I grant, are but ower friends, rather to be entertained then invited; yet 'tis too viible none are more wretched, then thoe that mot court fortune. Give mee Indifferency and I'le bee fortunes fate, and fortunate, maugre her depight. As to time it elf, the bet decription of it, is to employ it well. 'Tis a thing of o wift an Eence, that 'tis gone before we can think what it is. 'Tis the meaure of ublunary beings, and proclaimes to us, (by its height) how fat wee our elves fade, and dwindle away. The pat is no more ours, then frugall uage has made it o. The future is not; and o, uncertain whether 'twill ever be in our power. What of it we can own is only the preent, and this o coy, that if not taken by the oretop, 'tis vaniht, like a Ghot and leaves us nothing, but caue to repent and gaze. Ah! my friend, how pretious our moments; on thee hort Intances depends our whole Eternity. Temporall exitence is as fickle as temporall happinee; both participate of the nature of time, are fleeting • In this caualty then, let us fix on what is truely durable: above floating incertainties, beyond temporall latingnee. Whilt our minutes fly from us, our elves peed fater towards unchangeable permanency, o we doe in naturall tendency; but let us by virtue's vigours. Each hour pots away with it's length of our life; The old year is gone, if ou • imperfections with it, 'twas well pent; if not, there's the more ne • d we pend the New better
And let we live not to the end, let's take advantage of the begining: make that our own that is o. Thrift of our dayes is th' only end to make our elves in time eternally happy. But I fear by this rude Rhapody of the initiate yeare, I have wated your hourglas too much, rendring my prayer of your properous future, your preent Domage; But pardon, becaue my ubject (time) as wel as my ditracted capacity fail'd me. Suffice it, I wih you more then I can utter or need percribe you the way to; and whilt you are blet, I patrake

closer.signed: Your happy friend and joy'd ervant. W.D.

div.head: XXXIV. To a Lady, reiding in a Town that had lately bin beiegd.
div.p:
AFter the diquiet of your late Alarms, I am bold to congratulate the re-enjoyment of your wonted repoe, which (had I bin Generall) no caue nor quarrel hould have made me hazard; ince in all things I value your content above my own; My regard to your afety had bin in uch cae motive enough with mee, to have upended the chatiment of that mutinous City. Madam, If (as I hope and pray) you are now both free from di • uietude and from fear; I have my hearts wih; deiring (as you know) nothing more, then by continued devotion to your
elf and ervice; to purchae at length the eteem of

div.head: XXXV. To his Lady Mri•, complaining of her cruelty.
div.p: TYranny as ill becomes a ubject as a Prince, and cruelty is the natural iue of that Monter; To ay your Ladyhip is guilty of both in ome kind, is a truth undeniable: For ever ince fortune made me happy in your knowledge, my affection hath had no Centre, but your breat; my faith, no fellow; and my contancy uch as can never admit a change; yet my ighes are unpittied, my love unregarded, my faith and contancy anwered with nothing, but your diproportionate denialls; Nor can I, without wonder, conider, that your Ladyhip hould be <> all the world o perfectly charitable, to mee o cruell, unles 'twere ordained by fate, That the firt fruits of my love (which hould be the firt tep to happines) mut be made abortive by your incompaion. Madam, the more you deny, the more fuel you add to thoe flames, which (if not uddenly allai'd by your pittie) will conume my very being into ahes of mortalitie; Thee are Madam, the reall dictates of a heart, that's wholly ben •

div.head: XXXVI. A conolatory letter to a Mother upon the death of her firt born
div.p:
THe ad need a Comforter, and a Soul, in deolation, requires to bee aited with reaons to bear the caue of its griefs. That you are both ad and grieved, I can no more doubt, then I can be without a hare in your paions. That you have many comforters, becaue friends, many olid coniderations from your own pietie and pious widome to alve your orrowes, I am as confident; Yet as none more tenders your happinee then my elf, o could not I alone be ilent in this motive of your teares; what I would ay is, Dearet Madam, be comforted, and this (were't in my power) I would effect. The reaon of your able thoughts, the pring that treames your cheekes, rie I know from the ad accident of your childs death. It was I confes the firt image of your likenes, the firt ble •• g that heaven honored your body with, the firt pledge of nature, the firt title you had to be a Mother. And to bee deprived of this, almot as oon as 'twas given, could not but find and afford matter both for teares and grief, in a dipoition o natural and good. But Madam, there's a time for all, and a meane alo. What could not be denied to your weetnes, mut be moderated by your dicretion. 'Tis true, that weet infant was yours, 'twas your firt, 'twas dear, and you uffered many dolours, to give it life; But withall you conider, as 'twas yours, o given you by God; as the firt, o more due to him; as dear,
yet could it not be too dear for him that hath it; Although of painfull birth; yet that your throwes brought forth a Saint, that your dolours were endured, o oon to enthrone a part of your elf among the Angels; thee dolours, thee throwes, happily uffered. Thoe whom God makes Parents, he makes but Nures of his own children, he lends them to be brought up for heaven: and if hee hath o oon dicharged you of this obligation, tis not o much a cros, as a bleing; Had it lived to mature age, perhaps he aw danger both to It and you: it might have been more caue of grief to you, more los to it elf; it might have been unfortunate in life, in death unhappy; 'Tis not the being children of either good or great extract, that makes them alwayes either good or happy. And this perhaps God (that provident Parent of all) foreaw. Be it o, or not, certaine it is, the bodies but the ouls prion, wherein 'tis no oner breathed from Heaven, but 'tis maculated by this corrupt Earth: and in this, as it longer ojournes, o is it not only debarred of its true happines & welfare, but alo offends its great Creator; and conequently is mierable. Therefore would God make the cradle of yours, its death bed, that he might haten its blie. As he breathed a pure oul into it, o would he again take it before defiled by the actuall blemihes of in. Had it liv'd, it could have afforded no comfort to your piety, but being in health, properity, and pious; and can it be more pious, then in heaven, more properous, then in heavens joyes, more healthfull then in the enjoyance of immortality. O conider, tis now pat all danger, 'tis freed from all miery, 'tis bleed in bleednes, it prayes for you. And can there be any orrow o great that thee coniderations cannot
conolate? O what more happy then to be o happy a Mother; no ooner a Mother, then a Mother to heaven. Nor doubt (dear Madam,) but hee that gave you this dear pledge of his love, will give you more, and, as he took this to his own joyes, o will he leave in its tead more to your comfort. This he took to give it as oon happines as being, and therein to try your virtue and reignation to his will: this as I doubt not but he will find, o may you be confident he will bee bountifull: a ure rewarder, of your patience, a properer of your oul, body, and its fruitfulnes. But pardon (mot honoured Madam) my loves redounes; and if in this unpolihd Conolatory I have errd, let it be as it is loves fault, a fault that your noblenes I am certain will remit. Thus with humblet repects he takes his leave that will no longer bee, then be yours, the daily Petitioner to heaven for your mot wihed comforts of both Worlds.

closer.signed: Your humble and mot affectionate ervant, D.W.

div.head: XXXVII. To excue the not anwering a letter.
div.p:
THat I have committed o great a Solaecime in good manners, as to receive two letters from you, without giving you humble thanks for either; I beeech you acribe not to any want of zeal to your ervice; for in earnet you cannot make me more happy, then in vouch afing mee the
honour of your commands, which hall alwayes find as ready an obedience in mee, as any thing that mot concernes my own interet; In the aurance •• ereof I give you the humble repects of

div.head: XXXVIII. pon a Motion of marriage.
div.p: I Give you many humble thanks, for your tendring mee a wife, and your good advie in that affair; I well remember the Counell of a prudent friend was, not to marry till I were 30 years of age, and then to have a wife ten years younger then my elf; becaue women (epecially teeming ones) ooner decay, then men. I have alo read, that there are 3 principall motives to a wedded life; Procreatio Prolis: Conervatio Domus: and Conolatio vitae. Now the gentlewoman you write of, in tead of being ten years younger, I believe is ten years elder, then my elf; and o may be in danger to frutrate the two firt motives, by being iue-les. Yet if he have o many fill'd baggs as you mention, it may bee a hrewd temptation: But in marriage, Love (as you well oberve) is mot preferrable, provided there be a competency of fewel (which is riches) to keep it warm Now tis like I might love the Lady you motion mee unto, with an ordinary conjugall love, but perhaps not with an eminent dear affection, and on this ubject I remember to have read thee old but well meaning veres.

q.l: Who makes the object of his fancy, gold,
Grows cold-in fancy, when his money's told:
And he who faines to love, to live a Lady,
Is honors fawn, I know not what he may be.

div.p: Examples are too frequent in this age of the infelicity of thoe Matches, which are meerly concluded for wealth, without love: Therefore in this (as a choie, whereon the happines of my whole life depends) I hall be very deliberate in reolving, yet ever glad to receive your advie, as being

signed.hi: Your mot repective nephew and humble ervant.

div.head: XXXIX. The firt addree to his Mitree.
div.p:
THat fear is an individuall companion to incere affection, and that the heartiet devotions, are brokenly expreed, are Maximes in humanity, and however Errors, yet veniall; The dicreetet love is eldome without ome annexed paion, which oft-times fetters the faculties and leads undertanding captive; that which did and jutly might deter, doth now animate; The moon in her farthet ditance from the Sun, and greatet oppoition, receives mot light; The poorer they bee to whom charity is extended, the greater the merit; Worth gaines mot honour by enobling unworthines; Nature never ordaind two Suns to hine in one firmament. I lit not to expatiate
in this kind. In the dicription of your worth this hort expreion hall uffice; That would Earths Monarch pay his devotions before perfections Altar, he need eek no further then your breat. To expres my devoted affection by deep protets and multiplyed vowes doth nothing pleae, my Motto is, rather in deed then in word. Till matters be maturely dicued, and the advie of friends on both ides had, I aime no higher then to be entil'd your ervant; Deliberation (if in any cae) in this mot neceary. I honour you too much to wih you the mallet amis, though the um of my earthly felicity depended thereon. My affection is no frenzy; if my Starrs mean mee not the enjoying of uch happines, I mut frame a content. For concluion, I will only add, that though you may have your choice of many in all points more accomplihd, yet none that hall o truely love you; My lines are confued like my thoughts; your milder cenure hee perumes on, who truely honours your worth and rets

closer.signed: Solely devoted to your virtues. T. B.

div.head: LX. In anwer to an expotulatory letter.
div.p:
THe receipt of yours brought with it ome amazement to ee my elf almot hip-wrackt in your good opinion, when my own Veel was full fraught with repect, which I intended to di-imbark at your haven. I am firt to
thank you, for your plainnes and ingenuity in my charge, and hall aume the ame freedome in my own acquitall. The tory told you by Mr. W. from Mris. P. a womans dicoure (for thoe I uppoe the parties mentioned in yours) I deny to have been either Author or Promulgator of, and mut aure you, that uch like, with other volatile reports were here before my return; yet I mut tell you (ince it o much concernes mee) that I had Commiion to make ome inquiition in the Country upon a preconceived neglect in you, and other rumours, but do aure you, what I aid was with uch modety, and o hort of what common fame delivered, nay with uch regret to have aid any thing at all, that it will hereafter appeare, I have been o far from being diaffected to this your ervice, that I have run my elf into an Oblique opinion elewhere, for promoting it, and I am confident the young Lady (when you hall be felicitated with her enjoyment) will aure you amuch, nor indeed could I poibly have aid les, in performance of that trut which was repoed in mee. Sir, if this give you not atisfaction, I hall be glad to know what may, becaue I profee to owe you much ervice, and the more in order to that approaching happines, which your Starrs have aigned you, whereto no wihes of a happy confarreation hall more readily concurr, then thoe of

closer.signed: Your very humble ervant, T. B.

div.head: XLI. A REPLY.
div.p: TIll I was ble'd with the happy ight of yours I labour'd in a trange perplexity, believing that either the attempt of mine had purchaed your disfavour, or otherwie (by ome harder fate) I had uffered in your good opinion, then which Peru is to mee of lee value. Thee feares I mut confee with-held mee till now from a econd addree of ervice, though not from offering continuall thoughts of repect to your merit, and of perfect obedience to your commands, nor hall I longer live, then breath the air of uch devotion, being profeedly.

closer.signed: Yours in firme affection, T. B.

div.head: XLII. IN ANSWER.
div.p:
I Am (as you ay) indeed alwayes pleaed to accept, what time permits you to write. Your lines pleae, and cannot chue, being full of erudition, full of love, and guided by a judgement not vulgar; And, what ever your time is, your men • all tore • ailes not: what others with many a c • atched brow cannot invent, you with facility dictate, and as copiouly pen; Then for my acceptance, theres, no benignity required, but gratitude,
and gratitude not common, but uch as ought to quadre with merits impararelld. That you daigne to entertain mine but with a uperficiall view, adds honour and value, adds courage and alacrity. We ee many things carry price, not from innate worth, but the eteemers fancy: So Jewells and other rarities, which humane etimate and not nature, have made pretious: The rule is Opinion; and if any mans approbation could make my lines accurate (that is, what they are not) ooner to yours hould I yeeld the efficiency, and with much reaon; for there's none I approve more. Whilt I am jejune and empty, you are polite, and even upon my deficiencies, raie Trophies to your own Genius; Thus what I am not my elf, I make you, by accident; So increaes a black pot the candour of a blanchd veture; So gloomy hades eem to augment the Phaebean radiances, and o are your perfections et off by the foiles of

div.head: XLIII. A conceited letter of thanks for favours.
div.p:
YOu know that I (with friendhip and affection my ureties) tand already bound to you in an obligation, for requitall of a larger umme of favours, then my poore abilities can any wayes atisfy, yet now you make a large addition to the principall debt by— Till fortune better enable mee, I much beg your acceptance of thankfulnes, which I deigne in liew of interet, and (for you better
ecurity) my Bond renewed for the ret, with the addition of another urety, my ervice, eald with the privy ignet of my love, atteted by two witnees, gratitude and acknowledgment, and ubcribed by

div.head: XLIV. In anwer to a letter from a dear friend.
div.p:
OF late my many evocations render mee, as, incontant in reidency, o in my letters and addrees both various and uncertain; Hence have proceeded (and a while I fear mut) the languihment of my lines, the alteration of my weekes; Yet with this added diadvantage, that the more time may eem given mee to write, the les I have to be accurate. I received your lat abroad, and am never yet more at home, then where they find mee, or I them. A virtue that (with mee) accompanies yours, and yours only. And being it wants a name, let it be a Sympathy: a Sympathy 'twixt you and mee, o charming, that by reading your characters, I draw in my own Idea's (but abettered and o fall, by an introverion, into my elf. By this you may guee how much you endear your friend; by o expreing your elf his, to make him (even in the midt of ditractions, and fatigues) his own; and yet only to own him, to be more yours and Gods. Know then, I am yet free from misfortune, nor enfeebled by any mortall malady, that's enible; Some grudgings of a
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
Caduque being, and the unwholome eaons effects if I feel, they are but the antecedents of what I am ure at lat mut follow. But ince you tile my icknes, your infirmity, my infortunes, your mihapps, I would be well, to encreae your Vigours; fortunate to leen your leat bad events. The Heavens influence and their interpreting Predictions now we hear begin to work in your clime; and as the operation bodens tupendious revolutions, o are we tickled with curioity to know your changes, and • y what teps, the main Deignes are acended to? and what you conceive will be the equels, chiefly of neeret connexion? In the mean we will hope and feare; Two paions that will blend all the fore-cats of humane life. Be carefull of your health that you may enjoy your elf in a ditracted Age: So hall you bee afe in the guards of your own virtues; and in the innocency of your life, with comfort conolate your friends. Amongt whom not the leat dependent, is ever,

div.head: XLV. pon a promie to write to one.
div.p:
THe inconiderate promie I made to render you my thoughts in writing during this abence, was grounded upon a jut ence of my obligations, without the leat reflection upon my diabilities for any uch performance; And in this
repect I might jutly have been diobliged without breach of faith, but that (eriouly) I had rather dicover my imperfections in this kind, then be any waies wanting in my remerciaments, which are much indebted to your many favours: And therefore I end this mall tribute, as an earnet of the much greater affection of

closer.signed: Your coen and ervant, T. B.

div.head: XLVI.
div.p: AMong the various contentments, which the Country yeelds in this eaon, I have met with none equall to that which the receit of your letter affords mee; for (trut mee) I am o ravihed with the contents, that whenoever I perceive that adnes to invade mee, which the want of your weet preence often begets, I have intantly recoure to your letter for cure. Thus do I honour the lines for your dear ake that ent them, nor hall I ever ceae to acknowledge your numberles favours, whilt I have breath but to pronounce mee

closer.signed: Your mot affectionate Coen and ervant, T. B.

div.head: XLVII. In Anwer to an elegant letter.
div.p:
WHen I oberve the equall facility and felicity of your expreion, I loath the rudenes and indigetion of mine, and when I conider the pith and plenitude of your lines, I look upon the emptines and inainty of my own with much indignation: yet though I were not born a Cicero for Eloquence, I am and mut be another Achates for affection. If there bee any thing in this World can deerve the name of good, 'tis really in the fruition of you; in and by whom I am o perfectly beatified, that I count my elf in a Paradice, when I am gathering the fruits of your preence. Fortune (in other things les liberall) hath given mee many friends, and Correpondents, yet none o reall, none o learned, as your elf; I never made o happy a bargaine (if I may o rudely tile it) as when I contracted this intertrafique of love, I never hear from you or ee you, but I make an infinite purchae of piety, and knowledge, from your weighty lines and olid dicoure; But above all, I have gained (yet bluh to think with how little deert) in you a friend, whoe boome is an Archive, fit to treaure up the greatet ecret, and in whoe hands I can repoe my life, nay (which is dearer) my oul; O happines; happines aid I? 'tis beyond the degree of common happines; Such pious condecendings (where you give pure Gold and receive nothing but dros in exchange) argue a goodnes in you, beyond the reach of my pen to delineate, which I mut content my elf, to admire.
Sir, you have here the reall dictates of my inmot thoughts, though wrapt up in a homely dres; for I am as yet hardly entred into the Suburbs of good Language, yet do but pardon thee my rude expreions, & I may hope (by your conduct) in time to enter that City, where you, by due merit, command in chief. To morrow I am bound for the frigid Zone, yet will aure you, that no change of Climate hall have power to alter or frigidify the affections of

closer.signed: Your devoted ervant, and therein mot happy. T. B.

div.head: XLVIII. REPLY.
div.p:
YOurs, as a uddain joy, have urpried mee. So accort your tile, o pathetike your love, that I am both rapt and enflamed: you could never in better time have made your friendly addrees. They came as cordialls to refreh my exhauted Spirits. I was even pent in dipatches, ditracted with unexpected viits of friends. From thee, as a reviving refrigeration, I cat my eyes and thoughts on your emphatick traines. In which I am lot; Can wonder but not reply. In hort I am o variouly divided this day; and chiefly for the moments of the Meengers tay, that I have not repite of reply. Before you direct your coure, toward the North Pole, I hope to get o much paue, as to be my own, that I may make
ome uppletory addition. Pardon thee extemporaries: what in ene and language is deficient, that affection upplies, which really ever tiles mee

div.head: XLIX. A further reply.
div.p:
MY hetern note anwered yours, with apology, that I wanted time to anwer them; I promis'd alo to be more reponary, and now repent it. My leaure's as interrupted, and econd reviings of your accurate lines dianimate. What is mot delightfull to view, is as hard to paralell. Sir, the flote of your Eloquence runs high, and where (by the Art of elf-annihilation,) you would eem to depres your ufficiency, there you mot rie; And indeed kill cannot but by kill be hid, nor perpicuous abilities better blazond, then when mot curiouly mantled by arted invelopings. You are no Cicero born, 'tis confed, yet I think born to be an Englih Cicero; of this, nature has given ripe pecimens, and indutry as fat polihes, judgement matures. In one letter I trace you flourihing in various figures; in the property and tore of words choie, in c • mpoure compt; in ene acute. Trut mee, I admire, yet cannot envy; For whilt an Achates in affection, your embellihments are mine. The Acceory (you know) in Law follows the Principall, and love makes all common.
If then by this inviolable tie we are one, your endowments entitle me joinct owner; a riches, I prepone to Monarchies. Sir, I were happy did I rightly own the leat degree in the litterary attributes you pleae to give mee; thoe of endeared paion I doe; thoe of reality I cannot refue. It is indipenably your claime; what e're I am or hall be (that's commendable) is dedicated to your loyall friendhip; honour me with belief till I faile. My breat (as long as the harbour of a heart) hall be a afe repoitory; I was never by ingenerate dipoition futile and porous, and with o prudent and emboom'd a friend, I hall not ure begin. Upon ecrets I do not wittingly encroach, yet if (by freedom of a friend) committed, the gatly terrours of death unlock them not; He that wants this guit has no challenge to Amities acred interet. But I am now interturb'd, and my pen (dear friend) is natch'd off, yet firt take thee votary wihes; Propitious be your guiding Stars; inpiring the Mues; a afe journey; fortunately our expeditions, and a peedy circuit to your City entertainments and upir'd retires; It is almot your peculiar felicity, that, where others are chiefly cattered, you can find or make an improving eces; An evidence as you are tudious; o you can be, in all places, the commander of your elf and houres. Well! my loves, longings and prayers hall accompany this forcd vagary, and with as much joy welcome you home. Intertices locall may divide bodies & abodes; vinted minds know no eparation. Hence wherever I, in my better part, am with you concommitant, and latingly

div.head: L. ANSWER.
div.p: HItherto I have been in a uperlative degree, both felicitated by the riches of your preence and enriched by the wealth of your lines; But I have learnt there's nothing permanent in this world, otherwie 3 weeks abence from the one and deprivement of the other, would be more afflictive, then words can expres; For in earnet you are to me that fire of Prometheus, without which all my actions eem inanimate, detaine but the food of your favours from mee & I am a meer nothing. Though I am now bound (as you know) for the North, yet believe it my daily bet thoughts hall teer Wet-ward, where (how far oever ditant in peron) I leave the hearty affections of

div.head: LI. Anwer to a quaint Letter.
div.p:
WHen will your treaury of choie words be exhauted, when will your fountain of Eloquence be drawn dry, when will your Magazin of rich matter be emptied? never; I now plainly ee the more you write, the more you have to write, and may (with reverence) not ineptly compare your Cranium to
the holy Chrimatory of France; you till take out, yet leave it without the leat diminution; Prodigy of nature! It fares much otherwie with mee; I (if at any time big with words) fall into a painfull labour, and after many throwes, am alwaies by abortion diliver'd of a thing like a Bear's whelp, which I can lick into no form. Every Bucket drawn from mine own Well, goes neerer the bottome, the reaon is, there's no prings for repletion of that tore; yet in earnet the influence of your teeming Mue has (me thinks) in ome meaure fertilis'd my iccaneous and Barren oyle. But whether rove I? Now for News (which is the primum quaerite of thee dayes) I mut tell you, thus —Sir, the length of my letter and this hortet of daies doe not well quadre; This is the winter Soltice, So is it alo the tation both of my invention and paper, the firt is at a non p • us ultra of matter, the lat only affords me roome to ubcribe my elf

div.head: LII. To a Brother.
div.p:
YOurs equally full of love and good Councell came to my hands with no mall contentment, ince I perceive you interee your
elf (as a very kind friend) in all things that concern my good, which as I can never forget, o do I ever account my elf mot happy, when I hear of your progree in all perfections and good qualities, wherewith to ee you accomplihed is the paionate deire of

div.head: LIII. To Mr. G.
div.p: THis is only to give you many humble thanks for the favour you did mee to the D: If I live not to be able to trike Taleys with you, yet I hall alwaies record your kindnes with a thankfull reminicence: And though I am blunt in my expreion, yet believe it, I hall mot willingly in-Gage in any ervice that may approve mee

div.head: LIV. Another to him in Futian.
div.p:
MY lat was from Duntable, and (though I am in peron removed thence yet) I fear the matter of this may come from thence too, being not as yet ufficiently rudimented,
in your Accademy for uch uceptions. I mut tell you (with ome regret) that I find, not an Academick (except the noble Brittan) in all our voiinage; o that if we convere at all, it mut be with Labradors and uch out of whoe hebetudinous cerebroity, we may as oon extract A • rum potabile, as the Elixer of any knowledge; Their querilous outcry is, that the continuall iccity of this eaon, ha's inuted all their herbiferous grounds, which mny happily breed a dearth of Aliment, as there is already of litterature in thee parts. Thus much ex obliquo, now to the purpoe, I hope your late obtreperous Alarmes, have not interturbed the procedure of our noble Authors Micelany, which is a principall point in my Card. Sir, believe it without ome Miive of Conolation from you, the Country will oon put me into a Chagrin, therefore be no longer cotive, as you love

div.head: LV. ANSWER.
div.p:
HAving by the incloed given you ome few erious lines, let me now anwer your facetious letter (of 10 Augut) with a joculatory line or two; And firt by way of allauding your acuminous Exordium; but withall of hewing, you imediately mitake the word uception, if you think it can tand in a ober ence for undertanding, however in a way of Raillery it may pas. Again rudimented
for taught is harh; o is hebetudinous cerebroity. Documented for taught may pas in a erious Line, and plumbious, better then hebetudinous; for inuted, you hould ay exuted; o for herbiferous, frugiferous; becaue herbes and plants are the les principall children of the Earth; whereas Corn and all orts of grain are the mot principall for Mans ue; for o you mut mean by the word (aliment) that followes in the text of your letter.

And by this you ee there is a kind of Elegance to be oberved in a futian phrae; nay I ay more, the lepid lines of futian are lot, when 'tis not genuine but trained; And trut me (Sir) I hold it a piece of greater Art to line a letter with proper futian, then with ilken language, epecially when friends reolve to be merry by ditantiall alutes, your French Chagrin and Spanih Labrador may pas as appoite, becaue proper to the ene, and nothing trained; So the miive of Conolation you deire, by way of an amicable obervation upon the Text of yours; And this is what I can port away, who mut ret

div.head: LVI. REPLY.
div.p:
THis brings you humble thanks both for your news and your Criticimes, and though mine
of the 10 of Augut were but panis peuticus, a doghbak'd piece of futian, wherein I intended nothing ad amuim, yet you mut give me leave to make ome defence. For Suception I have Rider for my warrant in that ene; Rudimented I hold to be good and (according to the new mode of converting Nounes into Verbs) I purpoely avoided plumbeous cerebroity (not plumbious as you write it) as trite and thread bare; But for your exception to herbiferous, in that you mitake the ene, for the eaon hath bin of late very good for Corn and grain, which frugiferous includes, and as bad for gras, the Sun having in ome places not only burnt the very rootes of it, but has alo made trange clefts and impreions in the Earth, therefore I us'd inuted, a word which though not o uuall, as exuted, or aduted yet in this ene I think no les proper, if not in a genuine, at leat in a metaphoricall way, and Cattle, that are fed by gras & hay, are a coniderable part of our aliment, &c.

Sed me reprimo, not at all peruming to enter the Cirque with you in Logomachy or the pugnacity of uch diputes, but with ubmiion in all things to your greater judgment, whence I mut confes to have received in thee my junior years; a great increment to my maller portion of knowledge, both by thee and other your documentall redargutions, which I alwaies receive with a reverentiall repect, anwerable to your merit and the obligation of

div.head: LVII. Rejoynder.
div.p: I Do hugely allaud your endeavour to abonar what I had vitiated in my lat; For tis a igne you are Mater of what you do, when you can avow it ab ipis primis principiis, and thereby hew you are as far from being concious of errour, as you are from being incious how far you may ue the latitude of • utianiing, without exceeding the limits of modet avowment, per modum inculpatae tutelae, Macte animo mi Thoma, & perge eo quo cepiti pede, &c. Trut me Sir, I hall (without a bluh) eaily yeeld you the advantage of me in logomachy, as often times deep divines do to Logitians in point of reducing Syllogimes to all their poible variations into everall Moodes and figures; becaue the one is actually converant in that perticular, whereas the other depends only upon the habitual ue of uch figures, without retaining the rule that leads to the rectitude thereof; So men peak true Latine, without being able to give rule for it, and by this means ome times are peccant againt the Rule, which every chool-boy can correct them in. And truely in this perticular of Logomachy you may and will be able to read Lectures to the deepet of men, becaue you laudably make it your profes'd tudy and conequently will make a world of men obliged to you, as well as

div.head: LVIII. An Anwer from one ick.
div.p: SUch my perent condition, that I receive your letters as ick men do viits, am gratefull, yet cannot returne the curteie, but by feeble thanks; In this nature I have now been 3 weeks a decumbent; This the caue I have already faild in my wonted entercoure, and the ame continuate diability mut render thee, of my own complexion, infirm and faint, yet I beg you will not interrupt your turnes; For though I am not reponible, yet your lines are much olace and no mall divertiement from the ence of my weaknes: What was before but a friendly corepondence, will (till it pleae God I mend) be an office of endearing charity, extended towards him, who is

div.head: LIX. To his Mris, after a long Journey.
div.p:
I Have bin a long and ad journey, which eem'd o much the longer and o much the adder, by how much I was farther ditanced from your weet abode, nor had the adnes of this forc'd vagary any olace at all, aving that of neer 300 miles, I paed no one, without making a Relique of your
memory, which had till the vertue to renew all joyes in me, and expell the mits of melancholy, almot with equall force (o trong was my imagination) as if I had bin really in your preence; If you have but betowed one thought on me for every hundred I have dedicated to you, I am atisfied, believing that no love can come within o many degrees of mine, nor that there's any tate o happy, as that of being

div.head: LX. Another to the ame.
div.p:
THat you may ee I forget you not at any time nor in any place, I preent you thee, and if I eem importune by my frequent addrees, you mut pardon me, ince I profee to receive no olace in this abence, but what the comfortable entertainment of thoughts on you affords me, and hould I but as often put uch thoughts in writing, as my heart preents them to my memory, I hould be no day, even no houre without a pen in my hand; And I may well hope, from the excellency of your nature, that you will not leave uch faith, uch affection, without a jut retribution, nor can I depair of your remembrance of me in ome propor •• on anwerable to mine of you;
o may happines in the end crown both, and I live eternally

closer.signed: Yours, as at firt, unalterable, T.B.

div.head: LXI. In anwer to a friend, ill of a cold.
div.p:
THe next degree to the happines of not having evils, is to have had them: which imports, though not our immunity, yet riddance: & to have overcome annoiance may be better, then not to have uffered it. This ince you ay, you have bin almot dead of a Cold, congratulates your almot Reurrection: and hopes to find your hort-windednes turn'd into free repiration. 'Tis a vulgar Probleme, whether this malady may be called a dieae, or Phyick. You I believe found it trouble ome; but will not repent, if it prove medicinall. I imagin (allur'd by Aprils forward Sun) you lipt too early into your Summer Aparell; which, though it prov'd too thin to defend you, yet not unable, to make you take a warier choie of your Wardrobe next Spring. Gondamar was of opinion, as there were in England many eaons of the year in one day; o a man had need of everall uits: My fancy is, if you will not alwaies be hifting, 'tis bet not to hift till you ee nature in her bet Green gown: whoe fahion you may harmlely follow. Sir, you ee by my pinning out this one Claue of your letter, I want matter; Yet you may ee too,
there's nothing drops o raw from you, but affords ubject. Nor mut you blame me, if your indipoition buie my Pen, ince your < in non-Latin alphabet > is the Copie of it, and my own bet contitution. Hence you have a double care lies upon your preervation; your love to your elf, and indulgence to

div.head: LXIII. In anwer to a letter of Commends, &c.
div.p:
I Never look'd awry (pardon the phraie) upon any of yours till now, and now (were not our mutuall loves united with many a dear link) jealouie (that Canker of affection) would corrode my heart, I hould, and can yet hardly forbear to) judge, that you had ome more deerving object in your mind, when you fancied mee with uch high commends, as hold no proportion with my merit. I know you never wrote, but your heart and pen were coitinerants, yet (pardon mee, if) I aure you that in this (and perhaps in this alone) love has pourblinded your (otherwie much dicerning) judgment; hould I believe all your write of mee, I might quickly be wated into a Fools Paradie and o become a Ludibry; I'le rathet characterie my elf, then own the leat of your attributes, take it thus bluntly, yet with truth and candor, for I have tudied that Sentence, which was engraven upon the gate of Apollo's
Temple at Delphos (viz) < in non-Latin alphabet > . I was born under the dull planet Saturn, o that Mercury had no influence on my production, hence I am o far from being a Lynceus of nature, a Pelops of widome or Cicero of Eloquence, that I never pretended to any of thoe virtues, which beget admiration, nor to have my mind embroidered with any tudied ornaments of learning, I onely claime ome mall title to thoe qualities, which tir affection, As truth of word, incerity of heart, &c. Having thus ingenuouly premied, I now end you an inhibition from the Court of love, not to treat any more of that ubject, but to redargue my Errors and hew me the flats both of my pen and judgement, that what I write hereafter may merit this only Elogium; As here's no Elegance, o likewie no incongruity or affectation; I aim no higher; for in earnet if it were poible any thing of yours could naueate me, the way were to end me a Laudatory Epitle, intead of a redargutory letter; But I have another tak therefore tis high time to put Omega to this, by ubcribing my elf

div.head: LXIII. THE REPLY.
div.p:
MY fancied excee in your praie, now recoiles upon my elf; you are, I ee, your Artes Mater: and what you could not divert, by a jut diclaim; you can top, by an exaggerated
retorion. You may expect, I hould now imitate your hame-fac'd modetie; right this paper, with renouncing the abilities you heap upon me. But, I will not; hould I, We hould till dwell in one Theme, & by the Naueous tautologie, both impaire, what ere we both merit. I dare not vendicate to my elf, a perfect elf-knowledge; nay, I avoid the reflex glances, that hould tell me what I am; let, what I am, might cat me into a dejection; & o, hinder amendment. Puill animity, never yet attained an eminence. Do you ceae your own undervaluings, & I hall my more adjuted expreions. I can let your worths be their own blazons, would you o let them; but, if you will wrong you elf, jutice calls me, to your vindication. Nor, mut the Legits Maxime, here way; volenti non fit injuria. Neither of us (pardon the parallel) are o accompliht but we ought to thrive in imbellihments. Whether our ouls came Aritotles Tabula raa; or written with Plato's Idea's into our earth; in our earth, they have either forgot much, or learnt little. The fault, doubtles, ours. For, by what we know, we know we might, & may, know more. Nature, has made us capable; that we become not better Proficients, our own truant inertie, the obtacle. I, am not o much a Scotit, as to confee a ubtantiall difference, in ouls: nor yet, uch an Abcedary Philoopher, as to deny the Organs mut be fitted, where the operation is to be excellent. You, & I hould be ingrate, did we not aert, God has been liberall enough. To apere his bounty with our wants, were a petty blaphemie in Philoophie it elf. Let us both confee, our repective ignorance, & our ignorance to be onely ours. This done: we are not to center in old dulnee, but from the remore
of lot time, vigorouly imploy the future. It imports the Vulgar rout, more to be good, than agacious: We, are moulded for higher action: yet mut joyn Vertue to knowledge. Reaon's brutih, where the will's incult. The Patterne, we were effigiated to, was infinitely Knowing, infinitely good; in both, we are bound to imitate: bound to be the Repreentatives, of both, or, we forfeit our Orginall, and our imilitude, too. Man's a little world; his minde the Heaven; the two great Lights thoe plendid faculties, his Intellect, and Will: the leer Starres, are the other powers: the intellect the Sun of all: all borrow his brightnee, all mut Cooperate with his raies, by adding their proper vertues. Thus hall our Microcome be replendent and fruitful, & gloriouly rich: thus, we wie, and good, & thus nor good nor wie, I am.

div.head: LXIV. The Rejoinder.
div.p:
I Quarrell'd your lat in hope you would have retracted your trancendent elogicall conmends, which whilt you eem to intend in this, you have by a Rhetoricall Artifice, added more fewell to that fire; So that I perceive
whether I write or be ilent, complain or acquiece, I am every way dilemma'd; I mut confes to have nor wit nor language enough, to fadome the depth of your abilities, and by conequence am rendred impoibilited to pay you in your own coine, which is of uch allay, that I may well ay, you have truely found out the Philoophers tone, ince you are able to convert any gros matter into the gold of fine language; your proaick lines are (for excellency) like thoe metricall ones of Homer, which as they excell in other points, o they eem to have an eaie native lide in them, and to be conducted by a happy Genius. If I had abilitys to expatiate upon this ubject, I could not be held a Patelin, but rather a uffragran to truth; what I want words to expres, ilent admiration hall peak in the thoughts of

div.head: LXV. An Anwer.
div.p:
'TIs well you are, as you are, the Rendevouz where all perfections meet, otherwie I hould in this intercoure have one (and one onely) advantage of you; For whilt you at every return of the Tabellary, have your Theme to eek, and yet no ooner ought but found (uch is the magazin of your invention) I have a plentifull ubject alwaies ready at hand, If I had anwerable abilitys to make my election, and to
word it accordingly and that is news, news which whilt there are men, will never ceae to bee in vogue; And ince this week affords that which is omewhat palaticall, I hall no longer tantalize you with a proletarious Exordium. Then know, &c. —I humbly kis your hands and remain.

div.head: LXVI. REPLY.
div.p: I Am aaulted by your Martiall metaphors, yet with this favour, that where others erect their engines, to ruine, your levell aimes to trengthen the weak fort you direct againt; your continued Elogies at lat mean to perwade me (I ee) into ome Ability, and could you infue what you commend (in tead of bluh) your Rhetorique would make me doubtles eloquent. I will not ay with that keen Satyrit recuo Euge tuum & Belle. No I will with a modet guilt of non-deert embrace them, to profit, and that nec te quaeiveris extra (of the ame Poet) was a good Monition. But our Mue is not o toicall.

Praemia i tollas— Sir, honour is the reward of Artes and fame the tongue of honour, nor are either honour or fame more the guerdons, then the incentives of Proficience. Do you ee (my friend) how I hug your attributions? My vanity yet (in
it) may be your leon; not to be vain but ingenuous, Be not o queamih, hence forward: Accept your Baies offered, or merit it confer'd. What praie finds not anwerable, let it incite to anwer. I know my inufficiencies, but utterly depair not amendment; If by your encouragement I amend not, I hall confee my Brutih nature, to be pat cure. If I grant you an advantage over me, 'tis but what you have aerted: I anwer the ame Pot, and to many beides yours; But what is this? (my both matter, and the couching hewes it) to be uddainly light and rude, an odd perfection, and but uitable to both my leiure and me; you have a ready ubject for your pen, and how gratefully and ably you paint it forth, give me leave to be the Judge, that receive the delight: and I mut keep it to my elf, for you are as coy to receive the titles of your worth, as I am concious they are due. Be then till higher then words can expres you; o I may till bee

div.head: LXVII. The firt Addres to his Mitris.
div.p:
IN a caue whereon the felicity of my whole life depends, and wherein I have mot will, I find leat power to unboome the ecrets of my heart, uch force has love to captivate my faculties;
Hence 'tis I rather choe this, then that other way of verball delivery; For though in either I hould dicover my own imperfections, yet in thee lines my guiltles bluhes will pas uneen. Hitherto I have onely appear'd a ervant to your affaires, and in that quality had continued, if the excellency of your peronall endowments had not (by ome kind of heavenly impule) driven mee on to more apiring thoughts; Thoughts, which (with truth I peak it) were engendred by the onely object of your goodnes, without any adulterate commixture of etate, which (however valued by others) is not of weight ufficient to turn the ballance of my cale, if not otherwie well laden with pure and unbias'd affection, which I profes to owe to none but you; and to you all things, even the being of

closer.signed: Your mot faithfull and devoted ervant, T.B.

div.head: LXVIII. Another to the ame.
div.p:
IF the fumes of thoe corroives you gave me lat night from other hands, had not been qualified with the weet odors of your own cordialls, I had (unfeignedly peaking) wholly acrifiz'd the enuing night to the vigils of a diquiet mind; But as your goodnee had not the will onely, but the power to raie mee from a hell of tormenting thoughts, to a Paradie of
expected comfort, o does it multiply my endeared affections, which no mifortune hall have power to alienate, nor hall any thing but death determine. I am with much ollicitude etting all my imaginations upon the tenter, in order to the removall of thoe Rocks, which eem (and but eem) to threaten Shipwrack to our approaching happines, whereto your utmot contribution is (by all the ties of true love) mot earnetly implored, together with the continuance of him in your bet thoughts, who is

div.head: LXIX. ANOTHER.
div.p:
AMong all the obloquies, which the unrelenting malice of mine (and by conequence your) enimies hath cat upon mee, none appears o gatly in my thoughts, as that pretended want of love towards you, which (the heavens will witnes) was never imbreated in any mortall with more purity and plenitude; For 'tis the foundation, whereon I intend (by divine aitance) to build a frame of mutuall and interminable happines; a happines that will be admired by ome, but envied by others. Pleae to remember that you are now filia emancipata (as divines terme you) at your own dipoe, and that you have of mee a ervant, who only breathes by your favour and lives through your love, who will ever owe
you fealty for the one, and till do you homage for the other; a ervant, who with unwearied expectation only waits for the happy houre, wherein that (fiat) hall be by you pronounc'd, which will in an intant (Elixar-like) turn all my droy cares and anxieties into true contentments, and make me live eternally

div.head: LXX. ANOTHER.
div.p: IF a more preing occaion had not detain'd me, I hould have thought the foulnee of the weather but an eaie penance, in repect of the olace, which the weets of your preence would have afforded me; for the enjoyment whereof I mut (with much regret) adjourn my expectation till to morrow; Mean time I end you the promied pictures, if the ight of which do at any time erect your thoughts to heaven-ward, even then remember him, who on earth deires no greater happines, then to live and die loving (and beloved by) you, in quality of

div.head: LXXI. To excue the not taking leave of a Lady of quality.
div.p: THough it be held a readier way to gain pardon, by acknowledging then excuing a fault, yet the Eminency of your Ladyhips peron doth o aggravate it in me, that I mut beg leave to leen, though, I cannot hope to have it wholly remitted, in aying the jutnes of your Ladyhips caue of tay, made me preume none had o little compaion as to deny it; and that I might expect the being freed from my ague, without danger of loing the opportunity of preenting my humble thanks for o many ingall favours, undeervedly conferred on me; but ince that happines with many others is lot by your Ladyhips abence, honour this paper o far I beeech you, as to uffer it to upply my defects herein, and tetify how ambitious I hall be, by my future obervance, to merit the title of

div.head: LXXII. pon the death of a fair Lady.
div.p:
AMong other impartments, your lat tells mee, you were to uher a fair Lady to her grave; A
Corporall work of Mercy, it is to bury the Dead, I grant; but to interr o great a Beauty • e • ms to entrench on Pity and blat the Spring. Had he lived till Autumne or even Midommer, the funeralls of many flowers, had lamented her Urne: yea if but till they had been blown, they would have lot their lives to adorn her Heare; and have been ambitious (like thoe Savages) to have been buried quick with their Ladie Paragon, for her attendance in the other World. But he has inverted Nature, and the Seaon too; the flower of beauty died, when the beauty of flowers hould pring; and o has not onely left a withered World, but dimayed the Blowth of what hould garnih it. Flowers are diheartened to open their fragrant Colors, ince their Pattern is o early Cropt: and eem to intend (being he's entomb'd under the Earths urface) to keep themelves under Earth to accompany her dut; yet I will free you of cruelty in this fate; you had no hand (I am ure) in her death, though you helpt her to her Grave. And who hould be a fitter Mourner at the exequies of a fair Lady, than o compleat a ervant of Ladies? Sir, I ee what grace you are entertained with by them: they not only love you living, but are loath to part with you, dead: will carry you as for as they can towards the other life, when they goe. That if they may not have your company quite through (which were a wrong to Survivors) they may your funerall tears, ighes, or prayers for their ltime Vale: you preface a happy imprimis, to this ad dicoure, and ay having (firt) done all that might tend to her future happines. Happy News! and it ownes you, I believe, an intrument of good effects and offices. Had all fair Ladies uch faithfull ervants, More Idols of beauty would receive
impreion of the divine Image, and become the ervants of God. And he had much reaon to deire your care of her bodies enterrment, that had firt aided her oul, with a aving Viaticum for heaven. Long may you live the Author or helper of uch good deeds. In the interim, as here was a double work of mercy (Corporall and Spirituall) exploited; o you, I am confident, have made your uefull application of the Accident; beheld in the blating of this flower, the fate of Fairnes, the frailties of the fairet Clay, that feature, and white and red could embelih. If he were not Superlative in Beauty, in beauty he had many inferiours; if in fortunes, not the favourite of fortune; yet, he has had her miles. Many Beauties have faln ooner, many may ooner fade; yet in her all beauties, all fortunes, have expret, what fortunes and beauties are; what is the Exit of the Fable of this temporary life: to wit, ugly death, eternall deprivation, the cold Tomb, and deformed dut. Fortunate life! that o contemplates mortal condition, as to be indifferent and ready to change; that fraile incertainties, and vain glitter may be motives to aure and fix on lating good, that by others death learnes to live, and lives the life that feares not death: that o accompanies others funeralls, as in that able equipage, to behold the mournfull Pomp of the Worlds farewell, and their own detiny: that reads in that earthy bed of death (the Grave of others) their own Motto, we are dut, and all mortall things Momentary. Sir, pardon this long lip of my pen: you ee how a fair Ladies death and your living pietie, entrances me, to the forgetfulnes of other ubjects, I confes I am alo now in a dull Mood, not apt as to expreion. Thanks for your News on which, the only
preent comment hall be; that I am for ever

div.head: LXXIII. The Reply, relating the particulers of that Ladies death.
div.p:
SInce you have been pleas'd to ing o weet a dirge, and to make o excellent a comment upon our late funerous text, I cannot think the particulers of that ad ubject (how confuedly oever I deliver them) will be unacceptable to you; This Lady was 3 moneths continually dying, without any hope of recovery, and this occaioned by an ulcer in her throat, it was my good fortune (though others had aai'd it) to gain her firt aent to bring a pirituall Phiitian to her. Dr. G. was next at hand, and did act his part exceedingly well; after 2 or 3 effective viits, the Patient (through the comfort and eae of the pirituall Cataplames and emplaiters, which the Doctor applied) was o rapt and piouly enamor'd of him, as he even embrac'd him at every appearance. When hee drew neer the confines of deaths kingdom, he did uually ejaculate not only mot pious but even eloquent or rather diviniloquent expreions, as this (amongt many others) which heaven grant I may never forget. I have (aid he) lived long in the vanity of this World, for which God hath placed mee in this bed of orrow; Were it his
holy pleaure, I hould act over one of them again, and the choice left to mee, I would (by the Grace of Jeus) rather choe the torments of this bed, and malady, then have any thing to do with the Worlds vanities, &c Beides nothing did o much trouble her, as that he had lived (as he aid) for fear of Worldly endamagement) ome yeares in an outward profeion that contradicted her inward perwaion; The Doctor was no les taken with his Patient, then he with him, for I heard him ay hee was never more atisfied with the manner of any perons death; And I confes her exit did more trititiate mee, then did that of my own Siter, the manner of it, not a little both mortifying and edifying mee; For to ee her picture in the Anti-chamber, and then go in and look upon the originall, was ubject enough for mortification, the one being o incomparable beautifull, the other o ghatly; In a word, the lat breath he drew was Je-and in pronouncing-us he expir'd. So that we may conclude, as he was a great beauty living, he was a greater dead; For whereas corporall beauty in others dies with the body, hers did not o, but by a ecret tranition pas'd into the oul. div.head: LXXIV. LETTER.
div.p:
THe punihment that Apollo inflicts of reading Guicciardine is a light one, compar'd to this
that you impoe • pon your elf, and yet you will only here play the Stoick in not acknowledging you are in pain; Nothing can jutify mee, but obedience, for peruming to offer this tedious Romance to thoe eyes that hould onely look upon Iliads; I give veres as Galenits do Phiick, which clogs the tomack more then the dieae; I mut confes we may view Cities taken, kingdomes ruin'd, and new worlds dicovered in lee roome; It is a Poem that hath neither height nor profundity, yet it has length; it overflowes but wells not; it wearies without acents, as Promenades do upon a flat; In a word, I hall think, if you do not find fault with it and reprehend me, it is becaue you are angry and will do nothing in Paion; however it is a trut I recommend to your ecrecy, for follies are not things of the leat conequence to trut a friend with. And having now performed my promie with you, I expect you hould do the like with

div.head: LXXV. pon the New year.
div.p:
AS all things ublunary owe their being to the revolution of the upper Spheres, o their change; And 'tis jut, they hould ubmit to their eentiall Guides. Amongt other novelties, the firt mover had brought about the
point of Circular motion, that has began us a New year: and promies many unwonted effects. Whilt thee appeare, let us be the ame we were, contant old friends to God, heaven and our elves. Change, though to the better, argues imperfection, yet not to change to the better, were the wort of imperfections. As retles rivers hat to their Ocean, o ought we to ours, which is God, that Ocean of blis, repoe, and Center of aeternity; Till here arrived, we are in flux and variety: Let us be o, but hold the right way.

As Grace is elder then Nature, o he firt begins her year; Atronomers commence theirs with the prings vigour, when the Sun's in Aries, the Church is content with Capricorn; When her Sun's in the Cradle, that Orient of Jutice and mercy, the Son of God, The ignes melancholy; yet the forerunner of more propitious. So let our orrows horten with the nights, our joyes with the dayes lengthen. This oltice (if we follow the conduct of the right Star) will fairly move to a brighter height, a nearer approach; dipell our mits, warme our hearts, ravih our eyes.

This rambling prologue, is but to bring in the prayer that wihes you a happy New year, and that regard of times winged Cariers, which in running moments may take hold of the tedfat point of eternity. This is the Center of circumference; In which who truly fix, may be moved but not from it. Then, as time whirles away the meaure of our mortall being, it will ha • ten that, which hall know no alteration, but to be invariable. Sir, my complex • on uits the dead eaon at preent, and yeilds me but a languihing health: Hence my pen's as dull. You know when the bodies out of order, the pirits cannot but flag.
I mut uffer the one, you will pardon the other. And o to affaires that require no politure, but what your patience hall give them, &c.

div.head: LXXVI. ANSWER.
div.p: YOurs I have received, read, and read again, and the more I read it, the more I have a a mind to read it, uch are the incentives of your heaven-inpired lines, which as they clearly demontrate the truth of that Maxime of a modern Author, that Eternity is the Port and Sabbath of all humane Contemplations: So, ince my more earthy Soul and lee heavenly cogitations are not able in due manner to comprehend them; I wrap my elf in this your learned heet and ay to it (with equall wonder) As Aritotle once did to Euripus, Q • uia ego non capio te, tu capias me

div.head: LXXVII. A letter to a friend upon his marriage.
div.p:
I Have of late with held from you the Characters of my hand, though not the welwihes of my
heart, conceiving you as cloe in the puruit of your fair Daphne, as Phabus was of his, when the breath of his mouth diorder'd her disheiveld hair: For I perceive you have now ran o, as happily to take the Virgin-prize; may you be ever mutually happy. There now onely remains the metamorphois (not into the Beat with two backs, which the knavih Shakepear peaks of) but of that more ingenious, two into one, unus, una, into unum, which you have hinted o modetly in yours. Your Daphne I hope (before the arrivall of this paper) will be converted not onely into Bayes, but Roemary, which is one fragrancy, due to her perfections (if you have (as I doubt not) given her a true Character) more then the Poet gave Apollo's Mitres; Let this therefore uffice to give you both the parabien of Hymen's honours and felicities, and to let you know I hall both expect and be ambitious to wear a prig in honour of her, nor will I faile heartily to commend you both to the great Preident of the wedding of Cana in Galilee, that he may turn the bitter Waters of your long expectation into the Wine of a happy and contented life, made up with the bleing of a good and pious poterity. div.head: Supercriptions FOR LETTERS, to be addreed to all orts of perons, according to the uage of the preent times.
div.p: If to a Duke,
TO the mot Noble (and ome times) Excellent or illutrious Prince.
And in dicoure we tile him Grace
If to a Marques,
To the right Noble or right honourable.
And in dicoure his attribute is, Lordhip or Honour.
If to an Earle, Vicount or Baron
To the right honourable.
And to begin a Letter, we, either ay
May it pleae your Honor or Lordhip
Right honorable
My Lord.
Which lat is ued only by Lords to Lords, or by Gentlemen of ome quality, otherwie it is held too familiar.
If to a Baronet, or Knight of the Bath, we ay
To the honourable or much honoured.
And his attribute (in the beginning of a letter may be Much honored Sir.
The like may be given to a Collonel.
The uuall attribute of a Knight was of old
Right Worhipfull.
And of an Equire
Worhipful.
But thee are much dius'd, unles it be by perons of inferiour rank.
We ay (writing to a Knight)
To my noble or to my much honored friend,
Sir A.B. Knight, thee preent.
To an Equire we ay
To my much honored or mot worthy friend T.G. Equire.
Oberve that (when you write to an Eq) you be ure not to ay Mater T.G. Eq for the (Mater) is ridiculous, the Eq including it.

So if you write to a Doctor of Divinity, a Doctor of the Civil Law, or Doctor of Phiick, you mut not ay Mr. Doctor T.G. nor Doctor T.G. Eq; for Doctor both comprehends Mater and Equire, and of thee the Divine hath firt place, the Civilian next, and the Phiitian lat.
To an ordinary Gentleman thus,
To my approved friend
To my mot eteemed friend
To my much valued friend
To my very much repected friend
To my worthy good friend, or the like.

Note that all the younger Sons of Dukes and Marquees are Lords for their lives only, and are
called Lord John, or Lord William, &c. by their Chritian names.
The eldet Son of an Earle is a Lord by birth, o is not a Vicounts Son, till his Father be dead.
The younget Sons of Vicounts and Barons are but Equires, yet are honorable, and take place of all Baronets and Knights.
The eldet Son of a Baron is but an Eq during his Fathers life.

Equire (comes from the French Ecuier, in latin Armiger or Scutifer i. a bearer of Armes, or of a Sheild, and) is that Degree of Gentry, which is next to a Knight; It is conceived that at the firt thee Equires were bearers of Arms to Lords and Knights, and thereby had their name and dignity: Now to be true Equires according to the Law of Armes, they mut either be Lords younger Sons, Baronets or Knights eldet Sons, members of Parlement, Sheriffs, Jutices of the Peace, Serjeants at Law, Barriters at Law (yet the late Earle Marhall would not allow Barriters to be Equires, but in the Act for Polemoney they were ranked by the then Parliament as Equires and paid as Eq ) or of ome ancient family that has it by being heir to a Knight in the right line; Though now a dayes (I know not by what warrant) all Gentlemen that have but ome coniderable Etate in Lands, take that title upon them, when as the Etate (though never o great) adds no title. And that the title of Eq hould decend from Father to Son (as the Etate of Gentry doth) is meer fabulous, aies Mr. Herne in his Glory of Generoity, p. 100.
Ladies have (for the mot part) the ame attributes as their husbands.
Both in Letter and dicoure, we give a Dutches the title Grace.
But to a Marchiones, Countes, Vicountes or Barones, right honourable and in dicoure your honour, and among their equals, or in more familiar dicoure, Madam.

If you write to any of thee, the title Madam, is very moding, both at the beginning and end of your Letter, But if the peron writing be of much lower Rank, then the Lady written unto, it will be decent to ay.
May it pleae your honour, or Right honourable!
All the daughters of Dukes, Marqueses and Earles are Ladies by birth, and are called Lady Anne, Lady Mary, &c.

But the daughters of a Vicount or Baron are but Mitris, yet are honorable; And their Addition (being named in intruments of Law or Conveyances) is no more then a Yeomans daughter hath, and that is Spinter, wherein there eems to be ome title wanting.

And for the better undertanding the point of precedency, I have thought fit to trancribe an abtract of two Decrees made by King James touching the ame, in the 10 and 14 years of his raigne, which you may read more at large in Mr. Seldens, Titles of honour, Page 906.

p.hi: That the younger Sons of Vicounts and Barons hall take place and precedence before all Baronets.

div.p:
That such Bannerets (as hall be made by the Kings Majety, his heirs and Succeors, or by Henry now Prince of Wales, under his or their Standard diplayed
in an Army Royall in open war, and the King or Prince peronally preent) for their lives onely, and no longer, hall for ever in all places take place and precedence, as well before all other Bannerets whatoever, as likewie before the younger Sonnes of Vicounts and Barons, and before all Baronets.

p.hi: The younger Sons of Vicounts and Barons, and all Baronets, hall take place before all Bannerets whatoever, other then uch as hall be made by the King as aforeaid.

That the Knights of the Garter, Privy Councellors to the King, the Mater of the Court of Wards and Liveries, the Chancellor and under Treaurer of the Exchequer, Chanceller of the Dutchy, the chief Jutice of the Kings Bench, the Mater of the Rolls, The chief Jutice of the Common-pleas, the chief Baron of the Exchequer, and all other the Judges and Barons of the degree of the Coif of the aid Courts, hall have place before the younger ons of Vicounts and Barons, and before all Baronets.
That Baronets and their heires Males hall alwayes have place next unto the younger Sonnes of Vicounts and Barons, and their wives hall take place accordingly.

div.head: And in another Decree, 14 Jacobi.
div.p:
That the eldet onnes of Baronets and their wives as well during their husbands lives, as after; And the daughters of the ame Baronets following next after the aid wives of the eldet onnes of Baronets, hall have place and precedence before the eldet on
and the wife of the eldet onne of any Knight of what Order oever, And likewie the younger onnes of uch Baronets and their wives hall take place accordingly before the younger Sons of any Knights, &c.
